    3374         132 :         RenameTypeInternal(targetrelation->rd_rel->reltype,
    3375             :                            newrelname, namespaceId);
    3376             : 
    3377             :     /*
    3378             :      * Also rename the associated constraint, if any.
    3379             :      */
    3380         378 :     if (targetrelation->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_INDEX ||
    3381         134 :         targetrelation->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_PARTITIONED_INDEX)
    3382             :     {
    3383         112 :         Oid         constraintId = get_index_constraint(myrelid);
    3384             : 
    3385         112 :         if (OidIsValid(constraintId))
    3386          12 :             RenameConstraintById(constraintId, newrelname);
    3387             :     }
    3388             : 
    3389             :     /*
    3390             :      * Close rel, but keep lock!
    3391             :      */
    3392         244 :     relation_close(targetrelation, NoLock);
    3393         244 : }
    3394             : 
    3395             : /*
    3396             :  * Disallow ALTER TABLE (and similar commands) when the current backend has
    3397             :  * any open reference to the target table besides the one just acquired by
    3398             :  * the calling command; this implies there's an open cursor or active plan.
    3399             :  * We need this check because our lock doesn't protect us against stomping
    3400             :  * on our own foot, only other people's feet!
    3401             :  *
    3402             :  * For ALTER TABLE, the only case known to cause serious trouble is ALTER
    3403             :  * COLUMN TYPE, and some changes are obviously pretty benign, so this could
    3404             :  * possibly be relaxed to only error out for certain types of alterations.
    3405             :  * But the use-case for allowing any of these things is not obvious, so we
    3406             :  * won't work hard at it for now.
    3407             :  *
    3408             :  * We also reject these commands if there are any pending AFTER trigger events
    3409             :  * for the rel.  This is certainly necessary for the rewriting variants of
    3410             :  * ALTER TABLE, because they don't preserve tuple TIDs and so the pending
    3411             :  * events would try to fetch the wrong tuples.  It might be overly cautious
    3412             :  * in other cases, but again it seems better to err on the side of paranoia.
    3413             :  *
    3414             :  * REINDEX calls this with "rel" referencing the index to be rebuilt; here
    3415             :  * we are worried about active indexscans on the index.  The trigger-event
    3416             :  * check can be skipped, since we are doing no damage to the parent table.
    3417             :  *
    3418             :  * The statement name (eg, "ALTER TABLE") is passed for use in error messages.
    3419             :  */
    3420             : void
    3421       21318 : CheckTableNotInUse(Relation rel, const char *stmt)
    3422             : {
    3423             :     int         expected_refcnt;
    3424             : 
    3425       21318 :     expected_refcnt = rel->rd_isnailed ? 2 : 1;
    3426       21318 :     if (rel->rd_refcnt != expected_refcnt)
    3427           8 :         ereport(ERROR,
    3428             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_OBJECT_IN_USE),
    3429             :         /* translator: first %s is a SQL command, eg ALTER TABLE */
    3430             :                  errmsg("cannot %s \"%s\" because it is being used by active queries in this session",
    3431             :                         stmt, RelationGetRelationName(rel))));
    3432             : 
    3433       38310 :     if (rel->rd_rel->relkind != RELKIND_INDEX &&
    3434       33642 :         rel->rd_rel->relkind != RELKIND_PARTITIONED_INDEX &&
    3435       16642 :         AfterTriggerPendingOnRel(RelationGetRelid(rel)))
    3436           6 :         ereport(ERROR,
    3437             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_OBJECT_IN_USE),
    3438             :         /* translator: first %s is a SQL command, eg ALTER TABLE */
    3439             :                  errmsg("cannot %s \"%s\" because it has pending trigger events",
    3440             :                         stmt, RelationGetRelationName(rel))));
    3441       21304 : }
    3442             : 
    3443             : /*
    3444             :  * AlterTableLookupRelation
    3445             :  *      Look up, and lock, the OID for the relation named by an alter table
    3446             :  *      statement.
    3447             :  */
    3448             : Oid
    3449        3210 : AlterTableLookupRelation(AlterTableStmt *stmt, LOCKMODE lockmode)
    3450             : {
    3451        3210 :     return RangeVarGetRelidExtended(stmt->relation, lockmode,
    3452        3210 :                                     stmt->missing_ok ? RVR_MISSING_OK : 0,
    3453             :                                     RangeVarCallbackForAlterRelation,
    3454             :                                     (void *) stmt);
    3455             : }
    3456             : 
    3457             : /*
    3458             :  * AlterTable
    3459             :  *      Execute ALTER TABLE, which can be a list of subcommands
    3460             :  *
    3461             :  * ALTER TABLE is performed in three phases:
    3462             :  *      1. Examine subcommands and perform pre-transformation checking.
    3463             :  *      2. Update system catalogs.
    3464             :  *      3. Scan table(s) to check new constraints, and optionally recopy
    3465             :  *         the data into new table(s).
    3466             :  * Phase 3 is not performed unless one or more of the subcommands requires
    3467             :  * it.  The intention of this design is to allow multiple independent
    3468             :  * updates of the table schema to be performed with only one pass over the
    3469             :  * data.
    3470             :  *
    3471             :  * ATPrepCmd performs phase 1.  A "work queue" entry is created for
    3472             :  * each table to be affected (there may be multiple affected tables if the
    3473             :  * commands traverse a table inheritance hierarchy).  Also we do preliminary
    3474             :  * validation of the subcommands, including parse transformation of those
    3475             :  * expressions that need to be evaluated with respect to the old table
    3476             :  * schema.
    3477             :  *
    3478             :  * ATRewriteCatalogs performs phase 2 for each affected table.  (Note that
    3479             :  * phases 2 and 3 normally do no explicit recursion, since phase 1 already
    3480             :  * did it --- although some subcommands have to recurse in phase 2 instead.)
    3481             :  * Certain subcommands need to be performed before others to avoid
    3482             :  * unnecessary conflicts; for example, DROP COLUMN should come before
    3483             :  * ADD COLUMN.  Therefore phase 1 divides the subcommands into multiple
    3484             :  * lists, one for each logical "pass" of phase 2.
    3485             :  *
    3486             :  * ATRewriteTables performs phase 3 for those tables that need it.
    3487             :  *
    3488             :  * Thanks to the magic of MVCC, an error anywhere along the way rolls back
    3489             :  * the whole operation; we don't have to do anything special to clean up.
    3490             :  *
    3491             :  * The caller must lock the relation, with an appropriate lock level
    3492             :  * for the subcommands requested, using AlterTableGetLockLevel(stmt->cmds)
    3493             :  * or higher. We pass the lock level down
    3494             :  * so that we can apply it recursively to inherited tables. Note that the
    3495             :  * lock level we want as we recurse might well be higher than required for
    3496             :  * that specific subcommand. So we pass down the overall lock requirement,
    3497             :  * rather than reassess it at lower levels.
    3498             :  */
    3499             : void
    3500        3128 : AlterTable(Oid relid, LOCKMODE lockmode, AlterTableStmt *stmt)
    3501             : {
    3502             :     Relation    rel;
    3503             : 
    3504             :     /* Caller is required to provide an adequate lock. */
    3505        3128 :     rel = relation_open(relid, NoLock);
    3506             : 
    3507        3128 :     CheckTableNotInUse(rel, "ALTER TABLE");
    3508             : 
    3509        3122 :     ATController(stmt, rel, stmt->cmds, stmt->relation->inh, lockmode);
    3510        2410 : }
    3511             : 
    3512             : /*
    3513             :  * AlterTableInternal
    3514             :  *
    3515             :  * ALTER TABLE with target specified by OID
    3516             :  *
    3517             :  * We do not reject if the relation is already open, because it's quite
    3518             :  * likely that one or more layers of caller have it open.  That means it
    3519             :  * is unsafe to use this entry point for alterations that could break
    3520             :  * existing query plans.  On the assumption it's not used for such, we
    3521             :  * don't have to reject pending AFTER triggers, either.
    3522             :  */
    3523             : void
    3524          80 : AlterTableInternal(Oid relid, List *cmds, bool recurse)
    3525             : {
    3526             :     Relation    rel;
    3527          80 :     LOCKMODE    lockmode = AlterTableGetLockLevel(cmds);
    3528             : 
    3529          80 :     rel = relation_open(relid, lockmode);
    3530             : 
    3531          80 :     EventTriggerAlterTableRelid(relid);
    3532             : 
    3533          80 :     ATController(NULL, rel, cmds, recurse, lockmode);
    3534          80 : }
    3535             : 
    3536             : /*
    3537             :  * AlterTableGetLockLevel
    3538             :  *
    3539             :  * Sets the overall lock level required for the supplied list of subcommands.
    3540             :  * Policy for doing this set according to needs of AlterTable(), see
    3541             :  * comments there for overall explanation.
    3542             :  *
    3543             :  * Function is called before and after parsing, so it must give same
    3544             :  * answer each time it is called. Some subcommands are transformed
    3545             :  * into other subcommand types, so the transform must never be made to a
    3546             :  * lower lock level than previously assigned. All transforms are noted below.
    3547             :  *
    3548             :  * Since this is called before we lock the table we cannot use table metadata
    3549             :  * to influence the type of lock we acquire.
    3550             :  *
    3551             :  * There should be no lockmodes hardcoded into the subcommand functions. All
    3552             :  * lockmode decisions for ALTER TABLE are made here only. The one exception is
    3553             :  * ALTER TABLE RENAME which is treated as a different statement type T_RenameStmt
    3554             :  * and does not travel through this section of code and cannot be combined with
    3555             :  * any of the subcommands given here.
    3556             :  *
    3557             :  * Note that Hot Standby only knows about AccessExclusiveLocks on the master
    3558             :  * so any changes that might affect SELECTs running on standbys need to use
    3559             :  * AccessExclusiveLocks even if you think a lesser lock would do, unless you
    3560             :  * have a solution for that also.
    3561             :  *
    3562             :  * Also note that pg_dump uses only an AccessShareLock, meaning that anything
    3563             :  * that takes a lock less than AccessExclusiveLock can change object definitions
    3564             :  * while pg_dump is running. Be careful to check that the appropriate data is
    3565             :  * derived by pg_dump using an MVCC snapshot, rather than syscache lookups,
    3566             :  * otherwise we might end up with an inconsistent dump that can't restore.
    3567             :  */
    3568             : LOCKMODE
    3569        3290 : AlterTableGetLockLevel(List *cmds)
    3570             : {
    3571             :     /*
    3572             :      * This only works if we read catalog tables using MVCC snapshots.
    3573             :      */
    3574             :     ListCell   *lcmd;
    3575        3290 :     LOCKMODE    lockmode = ShareUpdateExclusiveLock;
    3576             : 
    3577        6806 :     foreach(lcmd, cmds)
    3578             :     {
    3579        3516 :         AlterTableCmd *cmd = (AlterTableCmd *) lfirst(lcmd);
    3580        3516 :         LOCKMODE    cmd_lockmode = AccessExclusiveLock; /* default for compiler */
    3581             : 
    3582        3516 :         switch (cmd->subtype)
    3583             :         {
    3584             :                 /*
    3585             :                  * These subcommands rewrite the heap, so require full locks.
    3586             :                  */
    3587             :             case AT_AddColumn:  /* may rewrite heap, in some cases and visible
    3588             :                                  * to SELECT */
    3589             :             case AT_SetTableSpace:  /* must rewrite heap */
    3590             :             case AT_AlterColumnType:    /* must rewrite heap */
    3591         714 :                 cmd_lockmode = AccessExclusiveLock;
    3592         714 :                 break;
    3593             : 
    3594             :                 /*
    3595             :                  * These subcommands may require addition of toast tables. If
    3596             :                  * we add a toast table to a table currently being scanned, we
    3597             :                  * might miss data added to the new toast table by concurrent
    3598             :                  * insert transactions.
    3599             :                  */
    3600             :             case AT_SetStorage: /* may add toast tables, see
    3601             :                                  * ATRewriteCatalogs() */
    3602          32 :                 cmd_lockmode = AccessExclusiveLock;
    3603          32 :                 break;
    3604             : 
    3605             :                 /*
    3606             :                  * Removing constraints can affect SELECTs that have been
    3607             :                  * optimized assuming the constraint holds true. See also

    3609             :                  */
    3610             :             case AT_DropConstraint: /* as DROP INDEX */
    3611             :             case AT_DropNotNull:    /* may change some SQL plans */
    3612         202 :                 cmd_lockmode = AccessExclusiveLock;
    3613         202 :                 break;
    3614             : 
    3615             :                 /*
    3616             :                  * Subcommands that may be visible to concurrent SELECTs

    3621             :             case AT_EnableAlwaysRule:   /* may change SELECT rules */
    3622             :             case AT_EnableReplicaRule:  /* may change SELECT rules */
    3623             :             case AT_EnableRule: /* may change SELECT rules */
    3624             :             case AT_DisableRule:    /* may change SELECT rules */
    3625         420 :                 cmd_lockmode = AccessExclusiveLock;
    3626         420 :                 break;
    3627             : 
    3628             :                 /*
    3629             :                  * Changing owner may remove implicit SELECT privileges
    3630             :                  */
    3631             :             case AT_ChangeOwner:    /* change visible to SELECT */
    3632          32 :                 cmd_lockmode = AccessExclusiveLock;
    3633          32 :                 break;
    3634             : 
    3635             :                 /*
    3636             :                  * Changing foreign table options may affect optimization.
    3637             :                  */
    3638             :             case AT_GenericOptions:
    3639             :             case AT_AlterColumnGenericOptions:
    3640          22 :                 cmd_lockmode = AccessExclusiveLock;
    3641          22 :                 break;
    3642             : 
    3643             :                 /*
    3644             :                  * These subcommands affect write operations only.
    3645             :                  */
    3646             :             case AT_EnableTrig:

    3676             :

    3681             :             case AT_ReAddDomainConstraint:  /* becomes AT_AddConstraint */

    3697             :                              * ShareRowExclusiveLock but requires further

    3702             :                         case CONSTR_FOREIGN:

    3707             :                              * as strong as CREATE TRIGGER.

    3710         370 :                             break;
    3711             : 
    3712             :                         default:
    3713         166 :                             cmd_lockmode = AccessExclusiveLock;
    3714             :                     }
    3715             :                 }
    3716         708 :                 break;
    3717             : 
    3718             :                 /*
    3719             :                  * These subcommands affect inheritance behaviour. Queries
    3720             :                  * started before us will continue to see the old inheritance
    3721             :                  * behaviour, while queries started after we commit will see
    3722             :                  * new behaviour. No need to prevent reads or writes to the
    3723             :                  * subtable while we hook it up though. Changing the TupDesc
    3724             :                  * may be a problem, so keep highest lock.
    3725             :                  */
    3726             :             case AT_AddInherit:
    3727             :             case AT_DropInherit:
    3728          56 :                 cmd_lockmode = AccessExclusiveLock;
    3729          56 :                 break;
    3730             : 
    3731             :                 /*
    3732             :                  * These subcommands affect implicit row type conversion. They
    3733             :                  * have affects similar to CREATE/DROP CAST on queries. don't
    3734             :                  * provide for invalidating parse trees as a result of such
    3735             :                  * changes, so we keep these at AccessExclusiveLock.
    3736             :                  */
    3737             :             case AT_AddOf:
    3738             :             case AT_DropOf:
    3739          20 :                 cmd_lockmode = AccessExclusiveLock;
    3740          20 :                 break;
    3741             : 
    3742             :                 /*
    3743             :                  * Only used by CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW which must conflict
    3744             :                  * with an SELECTs currently using the view.

    3746             :             case AT_ReplaceRelOptions:
    3747          54 :                 cmd_lockmode = AccessExclusiveLock;
    3748          54 :                 break;
    3749             : 
    3750             :                 /*
    3751             :                  * These subcommands affect general strategies for performance
    3752             :                  * and maintenance, though don't change the semantic results
    3753             :                  * from normal data reads and writes. Delaying an ALTER TABLE
    3754             :                  * behind currently active writes only delays the point where
    3755             :                  * the new strategy begins to take effect, so there is no
    3756             :                  * benefit in waiting. In this case the minimum restriction
    3757             :                  * applies: we don't currently allow concurrent catalog
    3758             :                  * updates.
    3759             :                  */
    3760             :             case AT_SetStatistics:  /* Uses MVCC in getTableAttrs() */

    3762             :             case AT_DropCluster:    /* Uses MVCC in getIndexes() */
    3763             :             case AT_SetOptions: /* Uses MVCC in getTableAttrs() */
    3764             :             case AT_ResetOptions:   /* Uses MVCC in getTableAttrs() */
    3765          58 :                 cmd_lockmode = ShareUpdateExclusiveLock;
    3766          58 :                 break;
    3767             : 
    3768             :             case AT_SetLogged:

    3771          18 :                 break;
    3772             : 
    3773             :             case AT_ValidateConstraint: /* Uses MVCC in getConstraints() */
    3774          32 :                 cmd_lockmode = ShareUpdateExclusiveLock;

    3776             :

    3781             :                  * decide between them using the basic grammar.

    3797             : 
    3798             :             case AT_CheckNotNull:

    3802             :                  * strong enough to prevent concurrent DROP NOT NULL.
    3803             :                  */
    3804           0 :                 cmd_lockmode = AccessShareLock;
    3805           0 :                 break;
    3806             :

    3811             :         }
    3812             : 
    3813             :         /*
    3814             :          * Take the greatest lockmode from any subcommand
    3815             :          */

    3818             :     }
    3819             :

    3821             : }
    3822             : 
    3823             : /*
    3824             :  * ATController provides top level control over the phases.
    3825             :  *
    3826             :  * parsetree is passed in to allow it to be passed to event triggers
    3827             :  * when requested.
    3828             :  */
    3829             : static void
    3830        3202 : ATController(AlterTableStmt *parsetree,
    3831             :              Relation rel, List *cmds, bool recurse, LOCKMODE lockmode)
    3832             : {
    3833        3202 :     List       *wqueue = NIL;
    3834             :     ListCell   *lcmd;
    3835             : 
    3836             :     /* Phase 1: preliminary examination of commands, create work queue */
    3837        6688 :     foreach(lcmd, cmds)
    3838             :     {
    3839        3554 :         AlterTableCmd *cmd = (AlterTableCmd *) lfirst(lcmd);
    3840             : 
    3841        3554 :         ATPrepCmd(&wqueue, rel, cmd, recurse, false, lockmode);
    3842             :     }
    3843             : 
    3844             :     /* Close the relation, but keep lock until commit */
    3845        3134 :     relation_close(rel, NoLock);
    3846             : 
    3847             :     /* Phase 2: update system catalogs */
    3848        3134 :     ATRewriteCatalogs(&wqueue, lockmode);
    3849             : 
    3850             :     /* Phase 3: scan/rewrite tables as needed */
    3851        2570 :     ATRewriteTables(parsetree, &wqueue, lockmode);
    3852        2490 : }
    3853             : 
    3854             : /*
    3855             :  * ATPrepCmd
    3856             :  *
    3857             :  * Traffic cop for ALTER TABLE Phase 1 operations, including simple
    3858             :  * recursion and permission checks.
    3859             :  *
    3860             :  * Caller must have acquired appropriate lock type on relation already.
    3861             :  * This lock should be held until commit.
    3862             :  */
    3863             : static void
    3864        3766 : ATPrepCmd(List **wqueue, Relation rel, AlterTableCmd *cmd,
    3865             :           bool recurse, bool recursing, LOCKMODE lockmode)
    3866             : {
    3867             :     AlteredTableInfo *tab;
    3868        3766 :     int         pass = AT_PASS_UNSET;
    3869             : 
    3870             :     /* Find or create work queue entry for this table */
    3871        3766 :     tab = ATGetQueueEntry(wqueue, rel);
    3872             : 
    3873             :     /*
    3874             :      * Copy the original subcommand for each table.  This avoids conflicts
    3875             :      * when different child tables need to make different parse
    3876             :      * transformations (for example, the same column may have different column
    3877             :      * numbers in different children).
    3878             :      */
    3879        3766 :     cmd = copyObject(cmd);
    3880             : 
    3881             :     /*
    3882             :      * Do permissions checking, recursion to child tables if needed, and any
    3883             :      * additional phase-1 processing needed.
    3884             :      */
    3885        3766 :     switch (cmd->subtype)
    3886             :     {
    3887             :         case AT_AddColumn:      /* ADD COLUMN */
    3888         456 :             ATSimplePermissions(rel,
    3889             :                                 ATT_TABLE | ATT_COMPOSITE_TYPE | ATT_FOREIGN_TABLE);
    3890         456 :             ATPrepAddColumn(wqueue, rel, recurse, recursing, false, cmd,
    3891             :                             lockmode);
    3892             :             /* Recursion occurs during execution phase */
    3893         452 :             pass = AT_PASS_ADD_COL;
    3894         452 :             break;
    3895             :         case AT_AddColumnToView:    /* add column via CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW */
    3896           6 :             ATSimplePermissions(rel, ATT_VIEW);
    3897           6 :             ATPrepAddColumn(wqueue, rel, recurse, recursing, true, cmd,
    3898             :                             lockmode);
    3899             :             /* Recursion occurs during execution phase */
    3900           6 :             pass = AT_PASS_ADD_COL;
    3901           6 :             break;
    3902             :         case AT_ColumnDefault:  /* ALTER COLUMN DEFAULT */
    3903             : 
    3904             :             /*
    3905             :              * We allow defaults on views so that INSERT into a view can have
    3906             :              * default-ish behavior.  This works because the rewriter
    3907             :              * substitutes default values into INSERTs before it expands
    3908             :              * rules.
    3909             :              */
    3910         166 :             ATSimplePermissions(rel, ATT_TABLE | ATT_VIEW | ATT_FOREIGN_TABLE);
    3911         166 :             ATSimpleRecursion(wqueue, rel, cmd, recurse, lockmode);
    3912             :             /* No command-specific prep needed */
    3913         166 :             pass = cmd->def ? AT_PASS_ADD_CONSTR : AT_PASS_DROP;
    3914         166 :             break;
    3915             :         case AT_AddIdentity:
    3916          14 :             ATSimplePermissions(rel, ATT_TABLE | ATT_VIEW | ATT_FOREIGN_TABLE);
    3917             :             /* This command never recurses */
    3918          14 :             pass = AT_PASS_ADD_CONSTR;
    3919          14 :             break;
    3920             :         case AT_SetIdentity:
    3921          10 :             ATSimplePermissions(rel, ATT_TABLE | ATT_VIEW | ATT_FOREIGN_TABLE);
    3922             :             /* This command never recurses */
    3923          10 :             pass = AT_PASS_COL_ATTRS;
    3924          10 :             break;
    3925             :         case AT_DropIdentity:
    3926           8 :             ATSimplePermissions(rel, ATT_TABLE | ATT_VIEW | ATT_FOREIGN_TABLE);
    3927             :             /* This command never recurses */
    3928           8 :             pass = AT_PASS_DROP;
    3929           8 :             break;
    3930             :         case AT_DropNotNull:    /* ALTER COLUMN DROP NOT NULL */
    3931          48 :             ATSimplePermissions(rel, ATT_TABLE | ATT_FOREIGN_TABLE);
    3932          46 :             ATPrepDropNotNull(rel, recurse, recursing);
    3933          44 :             ATSimpleRecursion(wqueue, rel, cmd, recurse, lockmode);
    3934          44 :             pass = AT_PASS_DROP;
    3935          44 :             break;
    3936             :         case AT_SetNotNull:     /* ALTER COLUMN SET NOT NULL */
    3937         290 :             ATSimplePermissions(rel, ATT_TABLE | ATT_FOREIGN_TABLE);
    3938             :             /* Need command-specific recursion decision */
    3939         288 :             ATPrepSetNotNull(wqueue, rel, cmd, recurse, recursing, lockmode);
    3940         288 :             pass = AT_PASS_COL_ATTRS;
    3941         288 :             break;
    3942             :         case AT_CheckNotNull:   /* check column is already marked NOT NULL */
    3943          28 :             ATSimplePermissions(rel, ATT_TABLE | ATT_FOREIGN_TABLE);
    3944          28 :             ATSimpleRecursion(wqueue, rel, cmd, recurse, lockmode);
    3945             :             /* No command-specific prep needed */
    3946          28 :             pass = AT_PASS_COL_ATTRS;
    3947          28 :             break;
    3948             :         case AT_SetStatistics:  /* ALTER COLUMN SET STATISTICS */
    3949          48 :             ATSimpleRecursion(wqueue, rel, cmd, recurse, lockmode);
    3950             :             /* Performs own permission checks */
    3951          48 :             ATPrepSetStatistics(rel, cmd->name, cmd->num, cmd->def, lockmode);
    3952          48 :             pass = AT_PASS_MISC;
    3953          48 :             break;
    3954             :         case AT_SetOptions:     /* ALTER COLUMN SET ( options ) */
    3955             :         case AT_ResetOptions:   /* ALTER COLUMN RESET ( options ) */
    3956          10 :             ATSimplePermissions(rel, ATT_TABLE | ATT_MATVIEW | ATT_INDEX | ATT_FOREIGN_TABLE);
    3957             :             /* This command never recurses */
    3958          10 :             pass = AT_PASS_MISC;
    3959          10 :             break;
    3960             :         case AT_SetStorage:     /* ALTER COLUMN SET STORAGE */
    3961          38 :             ATSimplePermissions(rel, ATT_TABLE | ATT_MATVIEW | ATT_FOREIGN_TABLE);
    3962          38 :             ATSimpleRecursion(wqueue, rel, cmd, recurse, lockmode);
    3963             :             /* No command-specific prep needed */
    3964          38 :             pass = AT_PASS_MISC;
    3965          38 :             break;

    4150             : 
    4151             : /*
    4152             :  * ATRewriteCatalogs
    4153             :  *
    4154             :  * Traffic cop for ALTER TABLE Phase 2 operations.  Subcommands are
    4155             :  * dispatched in a "safe" execution order (designed to avoid unnecessary
    4156             :  * conflicts).
    4157             :  */
    4158             : static void
    4159        3134 : ATRewriteCatalogs(List **wqueue, LOCKMODE lockmode)
    4160             : {
    4161             :     int         pass;
    4162             :     ListCell   *ltab;
    4163             : 
    4164             :     /*
    4165             :      * We process all the tables "in parallel", one pass at a time.  This is
    4166             :      * needed because we may have to propagate work from one table to another
    4167             :      * (specifically, ALTER TYPE on a foreign key's PK has to dispatch the
    4168             :      * re-adding of the foreign key constraint to the other table).  Work can
    4169             :      * only be propagated into later passes, however.
    4170             :      */
    4171       29280 :     for (pass = 0; pass < AT_NUM_PASSES; pass++)
    4172             :     {
    4173             :         /* Go through each table that needs to be processed */
    4174       55884 :         foreach(ltab, *wqueue)
    4175             :         {
    4176       29738 :             AlteredTableInfo *tab = (AlteredTableInfo *) lfirst(ltab);
    4177       29738 :             List       *subcmds = tab->subcmds[pass];
    4178             :             Relation    rel;
    4179             :             ListCell   *lcmd;
    4180             : 
    4181       29738 :             if (subcmds == NIL)
    4182       26176 :                 continue;
    4183             : 
    4184             :             /*
    4185             :              * Appropriate lock was obtained by phase 1, needn't get it again
    4186             :              */
    4187        3562 :             rel = relation_open(tab->relid, NoLock);
    4188             : 
    4189        6818 :             foreach(lcmd, subcmds)
    4190        3820 :                 ATExecCmd(wqueue, tab, rel,
    4191        3820 :                           castNode(AlterTableCmd, lfirst(lcmd)),
    4192             :                           lockmode);
    4193             : 
    4194             :             /*
    4195             :              * After the ALTER TYPE pass, do cleanup work (this is not done in
    4196             :              * ATExecAlterColumnType since it should be done only once if
    4197             :              * multiple columns of a table are altered).
    4198             :              */
    4199        2998 :             if (pass == AT_PASS_ALTER_TYPE)
    4200         210 :                 ATPostAlterTypeCleanup(wqueue, tab, lockmode);
    4201             : 
    4202        2998 :             relation_close(rel, NoLock);
    4203             :         }
    4204             :     }
    4205             : 
    4206             :     /* Check to see if a toast table must be added. */
    4207        5916 :     foreach(ltab, *wqueue)
    4208             :     {
    4209        3346 :         AlteredTableInfo *tab = (AlteredTableInfo *) lfirst(ltab);
    4210             : 
    4211             :         /*
    4212             :          * If the table is source table of ATTACH PARTITION command, we did
    4213             :          * not modify anything about it that will change its toasting
    4214             :          * requirement, so no need to check.
    4215             :          */
    4216        4324 :         if (((tab->relkind == RELKIND_RELATION ||
    4217        3968 :               tab->relkind == RELKIND_PARTITIONED_TABLE) &&
    4218        3674 :              tab->partition_constraint == NULL) ||
    4219         684 :             tab->relkind == RELKIND_MATVIEW)
    4220        2662 :             AlterTableCreateToastTable(tab->relid, (Datum) 0, lockmode);
    4221             :     }
    4222        2570 : }
    4223             : 
    4224             : /*
    4225             :  * ATExecCmd: dispatch a subcommand to appropriate execution routine
    4226             :  */
    4227             : static void
    4228        3820 : ATExecCmd(List **wqueue, AlteredTableInfo *tab, Relation rel,
    4229             :           AlterTableCmd *cmd, LOCKMODE lockmode)
    4230             : {
    4231        3820 :     ObjectAddress address = InvalidObjectAddress;

    4502             : /*
    4503             :  * ATRewriteTables: ALTER TABLE phase 3
    4504             :  */
    4505             : static void
    4506        2570 : ATRewriteTables(AlterTableStmt *parsetree, List **wqueue, LOCKMODE lockmode)
    4507             : {
    4508             :     ListCell   *ltab;
    4509             : 
    4510             :     /* Go through each table that needs to be checked or rewritten */
    4511        5848 :     foreach(ltab, *wqueue)
    4512             :     {
    4513        3344 :         AlteredTableInfo *tab = (AlteredTableInfo *) lfirst(ltab);
    4514             : 
    4515             :         /* Relations without storage may be ignored here */
    4516        3344 :         if (!RELKIND_HAS_STORAGE(tab->relkind))
    4517         946 :             continue;
    4518             : 
    4519             :         /*
    4520             :          * If we change column data types or add/remove OIDs, the operation
    4521             :          * has to be propagated to tables that use this table's rowtype as a
    4522             :          * column type.  tab->newvals will also be non-NULL in the case where
    4523             :          * we're adding a column with a default.  We choose to forbid that
    4524             :          * case as well, since composite types might eventually support
    4525             :          * defaults.
    4526             :          *
    4527             :          * (Eventually we'll probably need to check for composite type
    4528             :          * dependencies even when we're just scanning the table without a
    4529             :          * rewrite, but at the moment a composite type does not enforce any
    4530             :          * constraints, so it's not necessary/appropriate to enforce them just
    4531             :          * during ALTER.)
    4532             :          */
    4533        2398 :         if (tab->newvals != NIL || tab->rewrite > 0)
    4534             :         {
    4535             :             Relation    rel;
    4536             : 
    4537         296 :             rel = table_open(tab->relid, NoLock);
    4538         296 :             find_composite_type_dependencies(rel->rd_rel->reltype, rel, NULL);
    4539         292 :             table_close(rel, NoLock);
    4540             :         }
    4541             : 
    4542             :         /*
    4543             :          * We only need to rewrite the table if at least one column needs to
    4544             :          * be recomputed, we are adding/removing the OID column, or we are
    4545             :          * changing its persistence.
    4546             :          *
    4547             :          * There are two reasons for requiring a rewrite when changing
    4548             :          * persistence: on one hand, we need to ensure that the buffers
    4549             :          * belonging to each of the two relations are marked with or without
    4550             :          * BM_PERMANENT properly.  On the other hand, since rewriting creates
    4551             :          * and assigns a new relfilenode, we automatically create or drop an
    4552             :          * init fork for the relation as appropriate.
    4553             :          */
    4554        2394 :         if (tab->rewrite > 0)
    4555             :         {
    4556             :             /* Build a temporary relation and copy data */
    4557             :             Relation    OldHeap;
    4558             :             Oid         OIDNewHeap;
    4559             :             Oid         NewTableSpace;
    4560             :             char        persistence;
    4561             : 
    4562         166 :             OldHeap = table_open(tab->relid, NoLock);
    4563             : 
    4564             :             /*
    4565             :              * We don't support rewriting of system catalogs; there are too
    4566             :              * many corner cases and too little benefit.  In particular this
    4567             :              * is certainly not going to work for mapped catalogs.
    4568             :              */
    4569         166 :             if (IsSystemRelation(OldHeap))
    4570           0 :                 ereport(ERROR,

    4579             :                                 RelationGetRelationName(OldHeap))));
    4580             : 
    4581             :             /*

    4583             :              * local buffer manager is not going to cope.

    4586           0 :                 ereport(ERROR,

    4599             :             /*
    4600             :              * Select persistence of transient table (same as original unless
    4601             :              * user requested a change)

    4604         156 :                 tab->newrelpersistence : OldHeap->rd_rel->relpersistence;
    4605             : 
    4606         166 :             table_close(OldHeap, NoLock);
    4607             : 
    4608             :             /*
    4609             :              * Fire off an Event Trigger now, before actually rewriting the
    4610             :              * table.
    4611             :              *
    4612             :              * We don't support Event Trigger for nested commands anywhere,
    4613             :              * here included, and parsetree is given NULL when coming from
    4614             :              * AlterTableInternal.
    4615             :              *
    4616             :              * And fire it only once.

    4618         166 :             if (parsetree)
    4619         166 :                 EventTriggerTableRewrite((Node *) parsetree,
    4620             :                                          tab->relid,
    4621             :                                          tab->rewrite);
    4622             : 
    4623             :             /*
    4624             :              * Create transient table that will receive the modified data.
    4625             :              *
    4626             :              * Ensure it is marked correctly as logged or unlogged.  We have
    4627             :              * to do this here so that buffers for the new relfilenode will
    4628             :              * have the right persistence set, and at the same time ensure
    4629             :              * that the original filenode's buffers will get read in with the
    4630             :              * correct setting (i.e. the original one).  Otherwise a rollback
    4631             :              * after the rewrite would possibly result with buffers for the
    4632             :              * original filenode having the wrong persistence setting.
    4633             :              *
    4634             :              * NB: This relies on swap_relation_files() also swapping the
    4635             :              * persistence. That wouldn't work for pg_class, but that can't be
    4636             :              * unlogged anyway.
    4637             :              */
    4638         164 :             OIDNewHeap = make_new_heap(tab->relid, NewTableSpace, persistence,
    4639             :                                        lockmode);
    4640             : 
    4641             :             /*
    4642             :              * Copy the heap data into the new table with the desired
    4643             :              * modifications, and test the current data within the table
    4644             :              * against new constraints generated by ALTER TABLE commands.
    4645             :              */
    4646         164 :             ATRewriteTable(tab, OIDNewHeap, lockmode);
    4647             : 
    4648             :             /*
    4649             :              * Swap the physical files of the old and new heaps, then rebuild
    4650             :              * indexes and discard the old heap.  We can use RecentXmin for
    4651             :              * the table's new relfrozenxid because we rewrote all the tuples
    4652             :              * in ATRewriteTable, so no older Xid remains in the table.  Also,
    4653             :              * we never try to swap toast tables by content, since we have no
    4654             :              * interest in letting this code work on system catalogs.
    4655             :              */

    4662             :         }
    4663             :         else
    4664             :         {

    4682             : 
    4683             :     /*
    4684             :      * Foreign key constraints are checked in a final pass, since (a) it's

    4903             :              * Set all columns in the new slot to NULL initially, to ensure
    4904             :              * columns added as part of the rewrite are initialized to

    5117             : /*
    5118             :  * ATSimplePermissions
    5119             :  *

    5136         112 :             actual_target = ATT_VIEW;

    5234             : /*
    5235             :  * ATSimpleRecursion
    5236             :  *
    5237             :  * Simple table recursion sufficient for most ALTER TABLE operations.
    5238             :  * All direct and indirect children are processed in an unspecified order.
    5239             :  * Note that if a child inherits from the original table via multiple
    5240             :  * inheritance paths, it will be visited just once.
    5241             :  */
    5242             : static void
    5243         542 : ATSimpleRecursion(List **wqueue, Relation rel,
    5244             :                   AlterTableCmd *cmd, bool recurse, LOCKMODE lockmode)
    5245             : {
    5246             :     /*
    5247             :      * Propagate to children if desired.  Only plain tables, foreign tables
    5248             :      * and partitioned tables have children, so no need to search for other
    5249             :      * relkinds.
    5250             :      */
    5251        1012 :     if (recurse &&
    5252         568 :         (rel->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_RELATION ||
    5253         176 :          rel->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_FOREIGN_TABLE ||
    5254          78 :          rel->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_PARTITIONED_TABLE))
    5255             :     {
    5256         436 :         Oid         relid = RelationGetRelid(rel);
    5257             :         ListCell   *child;
    5258             :         List       *children;
    5259             : 
    5260         436 :         children = find_all_inheritors(relid, lockmode, NULL);
    5261             : 
    5262             :         /*
    5263             :          * find_all_inheritors does the recursive search of the inheritance
    5264             :          * hierarchy, so all we have to do is process all of the relids in the
    5265             :          * list that it returns.
    5266             :          */
    5267        1008 :         foreach(child, children)
    5268             :         {
    5269         572 :             Oid         childrelid = lfirst_oid(child);
    5270             :             Relation    childrel;
    5271             : 
    5272         572 :             if (childrelid == relid)
    5273         436 :                 continue;
    5274             :             /* find_all_inheritors already got lock */
    5275         136 :             childrel = relation_open(childrelid, NoLock);
    5276         136 :             CheckTableNotInUse(childrel, "ALTER TABLE");
    5277         136 :             ATPrepCmd(wqueue, childrel, cmd, false, true, lockmode);
    5278         136 :             relation_close(childrel, NoLock);
    5279             :         }
    5280             :     }
    5281         542 : }
    5282             : 
    5283             : /*
    5284             :  * Obtain list of partitions of the given table, locking them all at the given
    5285             :  * lockmode and ensuring that they all pass CheckTableNotInUse.
    5286             :  *
    5287             :  * This function is a no-op if the given relation is not a partitioned table;
    5288             :  * in particular, nothing is done if it's a legacy inheritance parent.
    5289             :  */
    5290             : static void
    5291         150 : ATCheckPartitionsNotInUse(Relation rel, LOCKMODE lockmode)
    5292             : {
    5293         150 :     if (rel->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_PARTITIONED_TABLE)

    5295             :         List       *inh;

    5297             : 
    5298          36 :         inh = find_all_inheritors(RelationGetRelid(rel), lockmode, NULL);
    5299             :         /* first element is the parent rel; must ignore it */
    5300         120 :         for_each_cell(cell, inh, list_second_cell(inh))
    5301             :         {
    5302             :             Relation    childrel;
    5303             : 
    5304             :             /* find_all_inheritors already got lock */
    5305          86 :             childrel = table_open(lfirst_oid(cell), NoLock);
    5306          86 :             CheckTableNotInUse(childrel, "ALTER TABLE");
    5307          84 :             table_close(childrel, NoLock);
    5308             :         }
    5309          34 :         list_free(inh);

    5313             : /*
    5314             :  * ATTypedTableRecursion
    5315             :  *

    5317             :  * Also check the RESTRICT/CASCADE behavior.  Given CASCADE, also permit

    5344             : 
    5345             : 
    5346             : /*
    5347             :  * find_composite_type_dependencies
    5348             :  *
    5349             :  * Check to see if the type "typeOid" is being used as a column in some table
    5350             :  * (possibly nested several levels deep in composite types, arrays, etc!).
    5351             :  * Eventually, we'd like to propagate the check or rewrite operation
    5352             :  * into such tables, but for now, just error out if we find any.
    5353             :  *
    5354             :  * Caller should provide either the associated relation of a rowtype,
    5355             :  * or a type name (not both) for use in the error message, if any.
    5356             :  *
    5357             :  * Note that "typeOid" is not necessarily a composite type; it could also be
    5358             :  * another container type such as an array or range, or a domain over one of
    5359             :  * these things.  The name of this function is therefore somewhat historical,
    5360             :  * but it's not worth changing.
    5361             :  *
    5362             :  * We assume that functions and views depending on the type are not reasons
    5363             :  * to reject the ALTER.  (How safe is this really?)
    5364             :  */
    5365             : void
    5366         838 : find_composite_type_dependencies(Oid typeOid, Relation origRelation,
    5367             :                                  const char *origTypeName)
    5368             : {
    5369             :     Relation    depRel;
    5370             :     ScanKeyData key[2];
    5371             :     SysScanDesc depScan;
    5372             :     HeapTuple   depTup;
    5373             : 
    5374             :     /* since this function recurses, it could be driven to stack overflow */
    5375         838 :     check_stack_depth();
    5376             : 
    5377             :     /*
    5378             :      * We scan pg_depend to find those things that depend on the given type.
    5379             :      * (We assume we can ignore refobjsubid for a type.)
    5380             :      */
    5381         838 :     depRel = table_open(DependRelationId, AccessShareLock);
    5382             : 
    5383         838 :     ScanKeyInit(&key[0],
    5384             :                 Anum_pg_depend_refclassid,
    5385             :                 BTEqualStrategyNumber, F_OIDEQ,
    5386             :                 ObjectIdGetDatum(TypeRelationId));
    5387         838 :     ScanKeyInit(&key[1],
    5388             :                 Anum_pg_depend_refobjid,
    5389             :                 BTEqualStrategyNumber, F_OIDEQ,
    5390             :                 ObjectIdGetDatum(typeOid));
    5391             : 
    5392         838 :     depScan = systable_beginscan(depRel, DependReferenceIndexId, true,
    5393             :                                  NULL, 2, key);
    5394             : 
    5395        2132 :     while (HeapTupleIsValid(depTup = systable_getnext(depScan)))
    5396             :     {
    5397         484 :         Form_pg_depend pg_depend = (Form_pg_depend) GETSTRUCT(depTup);
    5398             :         Relation    rel;
    5399             :         Form_pg_attribute att;
    5400             : 
    5401             :         /* Check for directly dependent types */
    5402         484 :         if (pg_depend->classid == TypeRelationId)
    5403             :         {
    5404             :             /*
    5405             :              * This must be an array, domain, or range containing the given
    5406             :              * type, so recursively check for uses of this type.  Note that
    5407             :              * any error message will mention the original type not the
    5408             :              * container; this is intentional.
    5409             :              */
    5410         398 :             find_composite_type_dependencies(pg_depend->objid,
    5411             :                                              origRelation, origTypeName);
    5412         390 :             continue;
    5413             :         }
    5414             : 
    5415             :         /* Else, ignore dependees that aren't user columns of relations */
    5416             :         /* (we assume system columns are never of interesting types) */
    5417         154 :         if (pg_depend->classid != RelationRelationId ||
    5418          68 :             pg_depend->objsubid <= 0)
    5419          66 :             continue;
    5420             : 
    5421          20 :         rel = relation_open(pg_depend->objid, AccessShareLock);
    5422          20 :         att = TupleDescAttr(rel->rd_att, pg_depend->objsubid - 1);
    5423             : 
    5424          20 :         if (rel->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_RELATION ||
    5425           0 :             rel->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_MATVIEW ||
    5426           0 :             rel->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_PARTITIONED_TABLE)
    5427             :         {
    5428          20 :             if (origTypeName)
    5429          10 :                 ereport(ERROR,
    5430             :                         (errcode(ERRCODE_FEATURE_NOT_SUPPORTED),
    5431             :                          errmsg("cannot alter type \"%s\" because column \"%s.%s\" uses it",
    5432             :                                 origTypeName,
    5433             :                                 RelationGetRelationName(rel),
    5434             :                                 NameStr(att->attname))));

    5476             : /*
    5477             :  * find_typed_table_dependencies

    5521             : 
    5522             : /*
    5523             :  * check_of_type
    5524             :  *
    5525             :  * Check whether a type is suitable for CREATE TABLE OF/ALTER TABLE OF.  If it
    5526             :  * isn't suitable, throw an error.  Currently, we require that the type
    5527             :  * originated with CREATE TYPE AS.  We could support any row type, but doing so
    5528             :  * would require handling a number of extra corner cases in the DDL commands.
    5529             :  * (Also, allowing domain-over-composite would open up a can of worms about
    5530             :  * whether and how the domain's constraints should apply to derived tables.)
    5531             :  */
    5532             : void
    5533          52 : check_of_type(HeapTuple typetuple)
    5534             : {
    5535          52 :     Form_pg_type typ = (Form_pg_type) GETSTRUCT(typetuple);
    5536          52 :     bool        typeOk = false;
    5537             : 
    5538          52 :     if (typ->typtype == TYPTYPE_COMPOSITE)
    5539             :     {
    5540             :         Relation    typeRelation;
    5541             : 
    5542          52 :         Assert(OidIsValid(typ->typrelid));
    5543          52 :         typeRelation = relation_open(typ->typrelid, AccessShareLock);
    5544          52 :         typeOk = (typeRelation->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_COMPOSITE_TYPE);
    5545             : 
    5546             :         /*
    5547             :          * Close the parent rel, but keep our AccessShareLock on it until xact
    5548             :          * commit.  That will prevent someone else from deleting or ALTERing
    5549             :          * the type before the typed table creation/conversion commits.
    5550             :          */
    5551          52 :         relation_close(typeRelation, NoLock);
    5552             :     }
    5553          52 :     if (!typeOk)
    5554           2 :         ereport(ERROR,
    5555             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),
    5556             :                  errmsg("type %s is not a composite type",
    5557             :                         format_type_be(typ->oid))));
    5558          50 : }
    5559             : 
    5560             : 
    5561             : /*
    5562             :  * ALTER TABLE ADD COLUMN
    5563             :  *
    5564             :  * Adds an additional attribute to a relation making the assumption that
    5565             :  * CHECK, NOT NULL, and FOREIGN KEY constraints will be removed from the
    5566             :  * AT_AddColumn AlterTableCmd by parse_utilcmd.c and added as independent
    5567             :  * AlterTableCmd's.
    5568             :  *
    5569             :  * ADD COLUMN cannot use the normal ALTER TABLE recursion mechanism, because we
    5570             :  * have to decide at runtime whether to recurse or not depending on whether we
    5571             :  * actually add a column or merely merge with an existing column.  (We can't
    5572             :  * check this in a static pre-pass because it won't handle multiple inheritance
    5573             :  * situations correctly.)
    5574             :  */
    5575             : static void
    5576         462 : ATPrepAddColumn(List **wqueue, Relation rel, bool recurse, bool recursing,
    5577             :                 bool is_view, AlterTableCmd *cmd, LOCKMODE lockmode)
    5578             : {
    5579         462 :     if (rel->rd_rel->reloftype && !recursing)
    5580           2 :         ereport(ERROR,
    5581             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),
    5582             :                  errmsg("cannot add column to typed table")));
    5583             : 
    5584         460 :     if (rel->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_COMPOSITE_TYPE)
    5585          16 :         ATTypedTableRecursion(wqueue, rel, cmd, lockmode);
    5586             : 
    5587         458 :     if (recurse && !is_view)
    5588         430 :         cmd->subtype = AT_AddColumnRecurse;
    5589         458 : }
    5590             :

    5777         594 :     CommandCounterIncrement();

    5779             :     /*

    5783             :     {
    5784             :         RawColumnDefault *rawEnt;
    5785             : 
    5786         130 :         rawEnt = (RawColumnDefault *) palloc(sizeof(RawColumnDefault));
    5787         130 :         rawEnt->attnum = attribute.attnum;
    5788         130 :         rawEnt->raw_default = copyObject(colDef->raw_default);
    5789             : 
    5790             :         /*
    5791             :          * Attempt to skip a complete table rewrite by storing the specified
    5792             :          * DEFAULT value outside of the heap.  This may be disabled inside
    5793             :          * AddRelationNewConstraints if the optimization cannot be applied.
    5794             :          */
    5795         130 :         rawEnt->missingMode = (!colDef->generated);
    5796             : 
    5797         130 :         rawEnt->generated = colDef->generated;
    5798             : 
    5799             :         /*
    5800             :          * This function is intended for CREATE TABLE, so it processes a
    5801             :          * _list_ of defaults, but we just do one.
    5802             :          */
    5803         130 :         AddRelationNewConstraints(rel, list_make1(rawEnt), NIL,
    5804             :                                   false, true, false, NULL);
    5805             : 
    5806             :         /* Make the additional catalog changes visible */
    5807         126 :         CommandCounterIncrement();
    5808             : 
    5809             :         /*
    5810             :          * Did the request for a missing value work? If not we'll have to do a
    5811             :          * rewrite
    5812             :          */
    5813         126 :         if (!rawEnt->missingMode)
    5814          16 :             tab->rewrite |= AT_REWRITE_DEFAULT_VAL;
    5815             :     }
    5816             : 
    5817             :     /*
    5818             :      * Tell Phase 3 to fill in the default expression, if there is one.
    5819             :      *
    5820             :      * If there is no default, Phase 3 doesn't have to do anything, because
    5821             :      * that effectively means that the default is NULL.  The heap tuple access
    5822             :      * routines always check for attnum > # of attributes in tuple, and return
    5823             :      * NULL if so, so without any modification of the tuple data we will get
    5824             :      * the effect of NULL values in the new column.
    5825             :      *
    5826             :      * An exception occurs when the new column is of a domain type: the domain
    5827             :      * might have a NOT NULL constraint, or a check constraint that indirectly
    5828             :      * rejects nulls.  If there are any domain constraints then we construct
    5829             :      * an explicit NULL default value that will be passed through
    5830             :      * CoerceToDomain processing.  (This is a tad inefficient, since it causes
    5831             :      * rewriting the table which we really don't have to do, but the present
    5832             :      * design of domain processing doesn't offer any simple way of checking
    5833             :      * the constraints more directly.)
    5834             :      *
    5835             :      * Note: we use build_column_default, and not just the cooked default
    5836             :      * returned by AddRelationNewConstraints, so that the right thing happens
    5837             :      * when a datatype's default applies.
    5838             :      *
    5839             :      * We skip this step completely for views and foreign tables.  For a view,
    5840             :      * we can only get here from CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW, which historically
    5841             :      * doesn't set up defaults, not even for domain-typed columns.  And in any
    5842             :      * case we mustn't invoke Phase 3 on a view or foreign table, since they
    5843             :      * have no storage.
    5844             :      */
    5845         590 :     if (relkind != RELKIND_VIEW && relkind != RELKIND_COMPOSITE_TYPE
    5846         574 :         && relkind != RELKIND_FOREIGN_TABLE && attribute.attnum > 0)
    5847             :     {
    5848             :         /*
    5849             :          * For an identity column, we can't use build_column_default(),
    5850             :          * because the sequence ownership isn't set yet.  So do it manually.
    5851             :          */
    5852         540 :         if (colDef->identity)
    5853             :         {
    5854           6 :             NextValueExpr *nve = makeNode(NextValueExpr);
    5855             : 
    5856           6 :             nve->seqid = RangeVarGetRelid(colDef->identitySequence, NoLock, false);
    5857           6 :             nve->typeId = typeOid;
    5858             : 
    5859           6 :             defval = (Expr *) nve;
    5860             : 
    5861             :             /* must do a rewrite for identity columns */
    5862           6 :             tab->rewrite |= AT_REWRITE_DEFAULT_VAL;
    5863             :         }
    5864             :         else
    5865         534 :             defval = (Expr *) build_column_default(rel, attribute.attnum);
    5866             : 
    5867         540 :         if (!defval && DomainHasConstraints(typeOid))
    5868             :         {

    5870             :             int32       baseTypeMod;

    5878             :                                                     (Node *) defval,
    5879             :                                                     baseTypeId,
    5880             :                                                     typeOid,
    5881             :                                                     typmod,
    5882             :                                                     COERCION_ASSIGNMENT,
    5883             :                                                     COERCE_IMPLICIT_CAST,
    5884             :                                                     -1);
    5885           2 :             if (defval == NULL) /* should not happen */
    5886           0 :                 elog(ERROR, "failed to coerce base type to domain");
    5887             :         }
    5888             :

    5890             :         {
    5891             :             NewColumnValue *newval;

    5894         128 :             newval->attnum = attribute.attnum;
    5895         128 :             newval->expr = expression_planner(defval);
    5896             : 
    5897         128 :             tab->newvals = lappend(tab->newvals, newval);
    5898             :         }
    5899             : 
    5900         540 :         if (DomainHasConstraints(typeOid))
    5901           4 :             tab->rewrite |= AT_REWRITE_DEFAULT_VAL;
    5902             : 
    5903         540 :         if (!TupleDescAttr(rel->rd_att, attribute.attnum - 1)->atthasmissing)
    5904             :         {
    5905             :             /*
    5906             :              * If the new column is NOT NULL, and there is no missing value,
    5907             :              * tell Phase 3 it needs to check for NULLs.
    5908             :              */

    5910             :         }
    5911             :     }
    5912             :

    6316             : /*
    6317             :  * ALTER TABLE ALTER COLUMN CHECK NOT NULL
    6318             :  *
    6319             :  * This doesn't exist in the grammar, but we generate AT_CheckNotNull
    6320             :  * commands against the partitions of a partitioned table if the user
    6321             :  * writes ALTER TABLE ONLY ... SET NOT NULL on the partitioned table,
    6322             :  * or tries to create a primary key on it (which internally creates
    6323             :  * AT_SetNotNull on the partitioned table).   Such a command doesn't
    6324             :  * allow us to actually modify any partition, but we want to let it
    6325             :  * go through if the partitions are already properly marked.
    6326             :  *
    6327             :  * In future, this might need to adjust the child table's state, likely
    6328             :  * by incrementing an inheritance count for the attnotnull constraint.
    6329             :  * For now we need only check for the presence of the flag.
    6330             :  */

    6340           0 :         ereport(ERROR,

    6343             :                         colName, RelationGetRelationName(rel))));
    6344             : 
    6345          10 :     if (!((Form_pg_attribute) GETSTRUCT(tuple))->attnotnull)
    6346           4 :         ereport(ERROR,

    6356             : /*
    6357             :  * NotNullImpliedByRelConstraints

    6360             : static bool

    6363         192 :     NullTest   *nnulltest = makeNode(NullTest);

    6923             : {

    6925             :     char        newstorage;
    6926             :     Relation    attrelation;

    6936          10 :         newstorage = 'p';

    6938          20 :         newstorage = 'e';

    6996             : 
    6997             : 
    6998             : /*
    6999             :  * ALTER TABLE DROP COLUMN
    7000             :  *
    7001             :  * DROP COLUMN cannot use the normal ALTER TABLE recursion mechanism,
    7002             :  * because we have to decide at runtime whether to recurse or not depending
    7003             :  * on whether attinhcount goes to zero or not.  (We can't check this in a
    7004             :  * static pre-pass because it won't handle multiple inheritance situations
    7005             :  * correctly.)
    7006             :  */
    7007             : static void
    7008         398 : ATPrepDropColumn(List **wqueue, Relation rel, bool recurse, bool recursing,
    7009             :                  AlterTableCmd *cmd, LOCKMODE lockmode)
    7010             : {
    7011         398 :     if (rel->rd_rel->reloftype && !recursing)
    7012           2 :         ereport(ERROR,
    7013             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),
    7014             :                  errmsg("cannot drop column from typed table")));
    7015             : 
    7016         396 :     if (rel->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_COMPOSITE_TYPE)
    7017          24 :         ATTypedTableRecursion(wqueue, rel, cmd, lockmode);
    7018             : 
    7019         394 :     if (recurse)
    7020         360 :         cmd->subtype = AT_DropColumnRecurse;
    7021         394 : }
    7022             : 
    7023             : /*
    7024             :  * Drops column 'colName' from relation 'rel' and returns the address of the
    7025             :  * dropped column.  The column is also dropped (or marked as no longer
    7026             :  * inherited from relation) from the relation's inheritance children, if any.
    7027             :  *
    7028             :  * In the recursive invocations for inheritance child relations, instead of
    7029             :  * dropping the column directly (if to be dropped at all), its object address
    7030             :  * is added to 'addrs', which must be non-NULL in such invocations.  All
    7031             :  * columns are dropped at the same time after all the children have been
    7032             :  * checked recursively.
    7033             :  */
    7034             : static ObjectAddress
    7035         576 : ATExecDropColumn(List **wqueue, Relation rel, const char *colName,
    7036             :                  DropBehavior behavior,
    7037             :                  bool recurse, bool recursing,
    7038             :                  bool missing_ok, LOCKMODE lockmode,
    7039             :                  ObjectAddresses *addrs)
    7040             : {
    7041             :     HeapTuple   tuple;
    7042             :     Form_pg_attribute targetatt;
    7043             :     AttrNumber  attnum;
    7044             :     List       *children;
    7045             :     ObjectAddress object;
    7046             :     bool        is_expr;
    7047             : 
    7048             :     /* At top level, permission check was done in ATPrepCmd, else do it */
    7049         576 :     if (recursing)
    7050         182 :         ATSimplePermissions(rel, ATT_TABLE | ATT_FOREIGN_TABLE);
    7051             : 
    7052             :     /* Initialize addrs on the first invocation */

    7054         576 :     if (!recursing)
    7055         394 :         addrs = new_object_addresses();

    7057             :     /*
    7058             :      * get the number of the attribute
    7059             :      */

    7064             :         {
    7065          12 :             ereport(ERROR,

    7082             :     /* Can't drop a system attribute */

    7084           2 :         ereport(ERROR,
    7085             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_FEATURE_NOT_SUPPORTED),

    7087             :                         colName)));

    7089             :     /*
    7090             :      * Don't drop inherited columns, unless recursing (presumably from a drop

    7094          16 :         ereport(ERROR,
    7095             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_TABLE_DEFINITION),

    7099             :     /*

    7112         530 :     ReleaseSysCache(tuple);

    7114             :     /*

    7221             : /*
    7222             :  * ALTER TABLE ADD INDEX
    7223             :  *
    7224             :  * There is no such command in the grammar, but parse_utilcmd.c converts
    7225             :  * UNIQUE and PRIMARY KEY constraints into AT_AddIndex subcommands.  This lets
    7226             :  * us schedule creation of the index at the appropriate time during ALTER.
    7227             :  *
    7228             :  * Return value is the address of the new index.
    7229             :  */
    7230             : static ObjectAddress
    7231         252 : ATExecAddIndex(AlteredTableInfo *tab, Relation rel,
    7232             :                IndexStmt *stmt, bool is_rebuild, LOCKMODE lockmode)
    7233             : {
    7234             :     bool        check_rights;
    7235             :     bool        skip_build;
    7236             :     bool        quiet;
    7237             :     ObjectAddress address;

    7239         252 :     Assert(IsA(stmt, IndexStmt));
    7240         252 :     Assert(!stmt->concurrent);
    7241             : 
    7242             :     /* The IndexStmt has already been through transformIndexStmt */
    7243         252 :     Assert(stmt->transformed);
    7244             : 
    7245             :     /* suppress schema rights check when rebuilding existing index */
    7246         252 :     check_rights = !is_rebuild;
    7247             :     /* skip index build if phase 3 will do it or we're reusing an old one */

    7250         252 :     quiet = is_rebuild;

    7252         252 :     address = DefineIndex(RelationGetRelid(rel),
    7253             :                           stmt,
    7254             :                           InvalidOid,   /* no predefined OID */

    7258             :                           check_rights,
    7259             :                           false,    /* check_not_in_use - we did it already */
    7260             :                           skip_build,
    7261             :                           quiet);
    7262             : 
    7263             :     /*
    7264             :      * If TryReuseIndex() stashed a relfilenode for us, we used it for the new
    7265             :      * index instead of building from scratch.  The DROP of the old edition of
    7266             :      * this index will have scheduled the storage for deletion at commit, so
    7267             :      * cancel that pending deletion.
    7268             :      */

    7371             : /*
    7372             :  * ALTER TABLE ADD CONSTRAINT

    7378         572 : ATExecAddConstraint(List **wqueue, AlteredTableInfo *tab, Relation rel,

    7389             :      * switch anyway to make it easier to add more code later.
