    7437             : 
    7438             : /*
    7439             :  * Generate the column-name portion of the constraint name for a new foreign
    7440             :  * key given the list of column names that reference the referenced
    7441             :  * table.  This will be passed to ChooseConstraintName along with the parent
    7442             :  * table name and the "fkey" suffix.
    7443             :  *
    7444             :  * We know that less than NAMEDATALEN characters will actually be used, so we
    7445             :  * can truncate the result once we've generated that many.
    7446             :  *
    7447             :  * XXX see also ChooseExtendedStatisticNameAddition and
    7448             :  * ChooseIndexNameAddition.
    7449             :  */
    7450             : static char *
    7451         358 : ChooseForeignKeyConstraintNameAddition(List *colnames)
    7452             : {
    7453             :     char        buf[NAMEDATALEN * 2];
    7454         358 :     int         buflen = 0;
    7455             :     ListCell   *lc;
    7456             : 
    7457         358 :     buf[0] = '\0';
    7458         816 :     foreach(lc, colnames)
    7459             :     {
    7460         458 :         const char *name = strVal(lfirst(lc));
    7461             : 
    7462         458 :         if (buflen > 0)
    7463         100 :             buf[buflen++] = '_';    /* insert _ between names */
    7464             : 
    7465             :         /*
    7466             :          * At this point we have buflen <= NAMEDATALEN.  name should be less
    7467             :          * than NAMEDATALEN already, but use strlcpy for paranoia.
    7468             :          */
    7469         458 :         strlcpy(buf + buflen, name, NAMEDATALEN);
    7470         458 :         buflen += strlen(buf + buflen);
    7471         458 :         if (buflen >= NAMEDATALEN)
    7472           0 :             break;
    7473             :     }
    7474         358 :     return pstrdup(buf);
    7475             : }
    7476             : 
    7477             : /*
    7478             :  * Add a check constraint to a single table and its children.  Returns the
    7479             :  * address of the constraint added to the parent relation, if one gets added,
    7480             :  * or InvalidObjectAddress otherwise.
    7481             :  *
    7482             :  * Subroutine for ATExecAddConstraint.
    7483             :  *
    7484             :  * We must recurse to child tables during execution, rather than using
    7485             :  * ALTER TABLE's normal prep-time recursion.  The reason is that all the
    7486             :  * constraints *must* be given the same name, else they won't be seen as
    7487             :  * related later.  If the user didn't explicitly specify a name, then
    7488             :  * AddRelationNewConstraints would normally assign different names to the
    7489             :  * child constraints.  To fix that, we must capture the name assigned at
    7490             :  * the parent table and pass that down.
    7491             :  */
    7492             : static ObjectAddress
    7493         320 : ATAddCheckConstraint(List **wqueue, AlteredTableInfo *tab, Relation rel,
    7494             :                      Constraint *constr, bool recurse, bool recursing,
    7495             :                      bool is_readd, LOCKMODE lockmode)
    7496             : {
    7497             :     List       *newcons;
    7498             :     ListCell   *lcon;
    7499             :     List       *children;
    7500             :     ListCell   *child;
    7501         320 :     ObjectAddress address = InvalidObjectAddress;
    7502             : 
    7503             :     /* At top level, permission check was done in ATPrepCmd, else do it */
    7504         320 :     if (recursing)
    7505         128 :         ATSimplePermissions(rel, ATT_TABLE | ATT_FOREIGN_TABLE);
    7506             : 
    7507             :     /*
    7508             :      * Call AddRelationNewConstraints to do the work, making sure it works on
    7509             :      * a copy of the Constraint so transformExpr can't modify the original. It
    7510             :      * returns a list of cooked constraints.
    7511             :      *
    7512             :      * If the constraint ends up getting merged with a pre-existing one, it's
    7513             :      * omitted from the returned list, which is what we want: we do not need
    7514             :      * to do any validation work.  That can only happen at child tables,
    7515             :      * though, since we disallow merging at the top level.
    7516             :      */
    7517        1280 :     newcons = AddRelationNewConstraints(rel, NIL,
    7518         320 :                                         list_make1(copyObject(constr)),
    7519         320 :                                         recursing | is_readd,   /* allow_merge */
    7520         320 :                                         !recursing, /* is_local */
    7521             :                                         is_readd,   /* is_internal */
    7522         320 :                                         NULL);  /* queryString not available
    7523             :                                                  * here */
    7524             : 
    7525             :     /* we don't expect more than one constraint here */
    7526         302 :     Assert(list_length(newcons) <= 1);
    7527             : 
    7528             :     /* Add each to-be-validated constraint to Phase 3's queue */
    7529         588 :     foreach(lcon, newcons)
    7530             :     {
    7531         286 :         CookedConstraint *ccon = (CookedConstraint *) lfirst(lcon);
    7532             : 
    7533         286 :         if (!ccon->skip_validation)
    7534             :         {
    7535             :             NewConstraint *newcon;

    7543             :         }
    7544             :

    7549         286 :         ObjectAddressSet(address, ConstraintRelationId, ccon->conoid);
    7550             :     }
    7551             : 
    7552             :     /* At this point we must have a locked-down name to use */
    7553         302 :     Assert(constr->conname != NULL);
    7554             : 
    7555             :     /* Advance command counter in case same table is visited multiple times */
    7556         302 :     CommandCounterIncrement();
    7557             : 
    7558             :     /*
    7559             :      * If the constraint got merged with an existing constraint, we're done.
    7560             :      * We mustn't recurse to child tables in this case, because they've
    7561             :      * already got the constraint, and visiting them again would lead to an
    7562             :      * incorrect value for coninhcount.
    7563             :      */
    7564         302 :     if (newcons == NIL)
    7565          16 :         return address;
    7566             : 
    7567             :     /*
    7568             :      * If adding a NO INHERIT constraint, no need to find our children.
    7569             :      */
    7570         286 :     if (constr->is_no_inherit)
    7571          16 :         return address;
    7572             : 
    7573             :     /*
    7574             :      * Propagate to children as appropriate.  Unlike most other ALTER

    7576             :      * use find_all_inheritors to do it in one pass.
    7577             :      */
    7578         270 :     children = find_inheritance_children(RelationGetRelid(rel), lockmode);
    7579             : 
    7580             :     /*

    7587             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_TABLE_DEFINITION),

    7596             :         /* find_inheritance_children already got lock */
    7597         128 :         childrel = table_open(childrelid, NoLock);
    7598         128 :         CheckTableNotInUse(childrel, "ALTER TABLE");
    7599             : 
    7600             :         /* Find or create work queue entry for this table */
    7601         128 :         childtab = ATGetQueueEntry(wqueue, childrel);
    7602             : 
    7603             :         /* Recurse to child */
    7604         128 :         ATAddCheckConstraint(wqueue, childtab, childrel,

    7612             : 
    7613             : /*
    7614             :  * Add a foreign-key constraint to a single table; return the new constraint's
    7615             :  * address.
    7616             :  *
    7617             :  * Subroutine for ATExecAddConstraint.  Must already hold exclusive
    7618             :  * lock on the rel, and have done appropriate validity checks for it.
    7619             :  * We do permissions checks here, however.
    7620             :  *
    7621             :  * When the referenced or referencing tables (or both) are partitioned,
    7622             :  * multiple pg_constraint rows are required -- one for each partitioned table
    7623             :  * and each partition on each side (fortunately, not one for every combination
    7624             :  * thereof).  We also need action triggers on each leaf partition on the
    7625             :  * referenced side, and check triggers on each leaf partition on the
    7626             :  * referencing side.
    7627             :  */
    7628             : static ObjectAddress
    7629         380 : ATAddForeignKeyConstraint(List **wqueue, AlteredTableInfo *tab, Relation rel,
    7630             :                           Constraint *fkconstraint, Oid parentConstr,
    7631             :                           bool recurse, bool recursing, LOCKMODE lockmode)
    7632             : {

    7649             : 
    7650             :     /*
    7651             :      * Grab ShareRowExclusiveLock on the pk table, so that someone doesn't

    7693             :     /*

    7878             :         {

    7880         364 :             ffeqop = get_opfamily_member(opfamily, fktyped, fktyped,
    7881             :                                          eqstrategy);
    7882             :         }
    7883             :         else
    7884             :         {
    7885             :             /* keep compiler quiet */
    7886          86 :             pfeqop_right = InvalidOid;
    7887          86 :             ffeqop = InvalidOid;
    7888             :         }
    7889             : 
    7890         450 :         if (!(OidIsValid(pfeqop) && OidIsValid(ffeqop)))
    7891             :         {
    7892             :             /*
    7893             :              * Otherwise, look for an implicit cast from the FK type to the
    7894             :              * opcintype, and if found, use the primary equality operator.
    7895             :              * This is a bit tricky because opcintype might be a polymorphic
    7896             :              * type such as ANYARRAY or ANYENUM; so what we have to test is
    7897             :              * whether the two actual column types can be concurrently cast to
    7898             :              * that type.  (Otherwise, we'd fail to reject combinations such
    7899             :              * as int[] and point[].)
    7900             :              */
    7901             :             Oid         input_typeids[2];
    7902             :             Oid         target_typeids[2];
    7903             : 
    7904          86 :             input_typeids[0] = pktype;
    7905          86 :             input_typeids[1] = fktype;
    7906          86 :             target_typeids[0] = opcintype;
    7907          86 :             target_typeids[1] = opcintype;
    7908          86 :             if (can_coerce_type(2, input_typeids, target_typeids,
    7909             :                                 COERCION_IMPLICIT))
    7910             :             {
    7911          16 :                 pfeqop = ffeqop = ppeqop;
    7912          16 :                 pfeqop_right = opcintype;
    7913             :             }
    7914             :         }
    7915             : 
    7916         450 :         if (!(OidIsValid(pfeqop) && OidIsValid(ffeqop)))
    7917          70 :             ereport(ERROR,
    7918             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_DATATYPE_MISMATCH),
    7919             :                      errmsg("foreign key constraint \"%s\" cannot be implemented",
    7920             :                             fkconstraint->conname),
    7921             :                      errdetail("Key columns \"%s\" and \"%s\" "
    7922             :                                "are of incompatible types: %s and %s.",
    7923             :                                strVal(list_nth(fkconstraint->fk_attrs, i)),
    7924             :                                strVal(list_nth(fkconstraint->pk_attrs, i)),
    7925             :                                format_type_be(fktype),
    7926             :                                format_type_be(pktype))));
    7927             : 
    7928         380 :         if (old_check_ok)
    7929             :         {
    7930             :             /*
    7931             :              * When a pfeqop changes, revalidate the constraint.  We could
    7932             :              * permit intra-opfamily changes, but that adds subtle complexity
    7933             :              * without any concrete benefit for core types.  We need not
    7934             :              * assess ppeqop or ffeqop, which RI_Initial_Check() does not use.
    7935             :              */
    7936           2 :             old_check_ok = (pfeqop == lfirst_oid(old_pfeqop_item));
    7937           2 :             old_pfeqop_item = lnext(fkconstraint->old_conpfeqop,
    7938             :                                     old_pfeqop_item);
    7939             :         }
    7940         380 :         if (old_check_ok)
    7941             :         {
    7942             :             Oid         old_fktype;
    7943             :             Oid         new_fktype;
    7944             :             CoercionPathType old_pathtype;
    7945             :             CoercionPathType new_pathtype;
    7946             :             Oid         old_castfunc;
    7947             :             Oid         new_castfunc;
    7948           2 :             Form_pg_attribute attr = TupleDescAttr(tab->oldDesc,
    7949             :                                                    fkattnum[i] - 1);
    7950             : 
    7951             :             /*
    7952             :              * Identify coercion pathways from each of the old and new FK-side
    7953             :              * column types to the right (foreign) operand type of the pfeqop.
    7954             :              * We may assume that pg_constraint.conkey is not changing.
    7955             :              */
    7956           2 :             old_fktype = attr->atttypid;
    7957           2 :             new_fktype = fktype;
    7958           2 :             old_pathtype = findFkeyCast(pfeqop_right, old_fktype,
    7959             :                                         &old_castfunc);
    7960           2 :             new_pathtype = findFkeyCast(pfeqop_right, new_fktype,
    7961             :                                         &new_castfunc);
    7962             : 
    7963             :             /*
    7964             :              * Upon a change to the cast from the FK column to its pfeqop
    7965             :              * operand, revalidate the constraint.  For this evaluation, a
    7966             :              * binary coercion cast is equivalent to no cast at all.  While
    7967             :              * type implementors should design implicit casts with an eye
    7968             :              * toward consistency of operations like equality, we cannot
    7969             :              * assume here that they have done so.
    7970             :              *
    7971             :              * A function with a polymorphic argument could change behavior
    7972             :              * arbitrarily in response to get_fn_expr_argtype().  Therefore,
    7973             :              * when the cast destination is polymorphic, we only avoid
    7974             :              * revalidation if the input type has not changed at all.  Given
    7975             :              * just the core data types and operator classes, this requirement
    7976             :              * prevents no would-be optimizations.
    7977             :              *
    7978             :              * If the cast converts from a base type to a domain thereon, then
    7979             :              * that domain type must be the opcintype of the unique index.
    7980             :              * Necessarily, the primary key column must then be of the domain
    7981             :              * type.  Since the constraint was previously valid, all values on
    7982             :              * the foreign side necessarily exist on the primary side and in
    7983             :              * turn conform to the domain.  Consequently, we need not treat
    7984             :              * domains specially here.
    7985             :              *
    7986             :              * Since we require that all collations share the same notion of
    7987             :              * equality (which they do, because texteq reduces to bitwise
    7988             :              * equality), we don't compare collation here.
    7989             :              *
    7990             :              * We need not directly consider the PK type.  It's necessarily
    7991             :              * binary coercible to the opcintype of the unique index column,
    7992             :              * and ri_triggers.c will only deal with PK datums in terms of
    7993             :              * that opcintype.  Changing the opcintype also changes pfeqop.
    7994             :              */
    7995           4 :             old_check_ok = (new_pathtype == old_pathtype &&
    7996           6 :                             new_castfunc == old_castfunc &&
    7997           2 :                             (!IsPolymorphicType(pfeqop_right) ||
    7998             :                              new_fktype == old_fktype));
    7999             :         }
    8000             : 
    8001         380 :         pfeqoperators[i] = pfeqop;
    8002         380 :         ppeqoperators[i] = ppeqop;
    8003         380 :         ffeqoperators[i] = ffeqop;
    8004             :     }
    8005             : 
    8006             :     /*
    8007             :      * Create all the constraint and trigger objects, recursing to partitions
    8008             :      * as necessary.  First handle the referenced side.
    8009             :      */
    8010         282 :     address = addFkRecurseReferenced(wqueue, fkconstraint, rel, pkrel,
    8011             :                                      indexOid,
    8012             :                                      InvalidOid,    /* no parent constraint */
    8013             :                                      numfks,
    8014             :                                      pkattnum,
    8015             :                                      fkattnum,
    8016             :                                      pfeqoperators,
    8017             :                                      ppeqoperators,
    8018             :                                      ffeqoperators,
    8019             :                                      old_check_ok);
    8020             : 
    8021             :     /* Now handle the referencing side. */
    8022         282 :     addFkRecurseReferencing(wqueue, fkconstraint, rel, pkrel,
    8023             :                             indexOid,
    8024             :                             address.objectId,
    8025             :                             numfks,
    8026             :                             pkattnum,
    8027             :                             fkattnum,
    8028             :                             pfeqoperators,
    8029             :                             ppeqoperators,
    8030             :                             ffeqoperators,
    8031             :                             old_check_ok,
    8032             :                             lockmode);
    8033             : 
    8034             :     /*
    8035             :      * Done.  Close pk table, but keep lock until we've committed.
    8036             :      */
    8037         282 :     table_close(pkrel, NoLock);
    8038             : 
    8039         282 :     return address;
    8040             : }
    8041             : 
    8042             : /*
    8043             :  * addFkRecurseReferenced
    8044             :  *      subroutine for ATAddForeignKeyConstraint; recurses on the referenced
    8045             :  *      side of the constraint
    8046             :  *
    8047             :  * Create pg_constraint rows for the referenced side of the constraint,
    8048             :  * referencing the parent of the referencing side; also create action triggers
    8049             :  * on leaf partitions.  If the table is partitioned, recurse to handle each
    8050             :  * partition.
    8051             :  *
    8052             :  * wqueue is the ALTER TABLE work queue; can be NULL when not running as part
    8053             :  * of an ALTER TABLE sequence.
    8054             :  * fkconstraint is the constraint being added.
    8055             :  * rel is the root referencing relation.
    8056             :  * pkrel is the referenced relation; might be a partition, if recursing.
    8057             :  * indexOid is the OID of the index (on pkrel) implementing this constraint.
    8058             :  * parentConstr is the OID of a parent constraint; InvalidOid if this is a
    8059             :  * top-level constraint.
    8060             :  * numfks is the number of columns in the foreign key
    8061             :  * pkattnum is the attnum array of referenced attributes.
    8062             :  * fkattnum is the attnum array of referencing attributes.
    8063             :  * pf/pp/ffeqoperators are OID array of operators between columns.
    8064             :  * old_check_ok signals that this constraint replaces an existing one that
    8065             :  * was already validated (thus this one doesn't need validation).
    8066             :  */
    8067             : static ObjectAddress

    8242             : 
    8243             : /*
    8244             :  * addFkRecurseReferencing
    8245             :  *      subroutine for ATAddForeignKeyConstraint and CloneFkReferencing
    8246             :  *
    8247             :  * If the referencing relation is a plain relation, create the necessary check
    8248             :  * triggers that implement the constraint, and set up for Phase 3 constraint
    8249             :  * verification.  If the referencing relation is a partitioned table, then
    8250             :  * we create a pg_constraint row for it and recurse on this routine for each
    8251             :  * partition.
    8252             :  *
    8253             :  * We assume that the referenced relation is locked against concurrent
    8254             :  * deletions.  If it's a partitioned relation, every partition must be so
    8255             :  * locked.
    8256             :  *
    8257             :  * wqueue is the ALTER TABLE work queue; can be NULL when not running as part
    8258             :  * of an ALTER TABLE sequence.
    8259             :  * fkconstraint is the constraint being added.
    8260             :  * rel is the referencing relation; might be a partition, if recursing.
    8261             :  * pkrel is the root referenced relation.
    8262             :  * indexOid is the OID of the index (on pkrel) implementing this constraint.
    8263             :  * parentConstr is the OID of the parent constraint (there is always one).
    8264             :  * numfks is the number of columns in the foreign key
    8265             :  * pkattnum is the attnum array of referenced attributes.
    8266             :  * fkattnum is the attnum array of referencing attributes.
    8267             :  * pf/pp/ffeqoperators are OID array of operators between columns.
    8268             :  * old_check_ok signals that this constraint replaces an existing one that
    8269             :  *      was already validated (thus this one doesn't need validation).
    8270             :  * lockmode is the lockmode to acquire on partitions when recursing.
    8271             :  */
    8272             : static void
    8273         428 : addFkRecurseReferencing(List **wqueue, Constraint *fkconstraint, Relation rel,
    8274             :                         Relation pkrel, Oid indexOid, Oid parentConstr,
    8275             :                         int numfks, int16 *pkattnum, int16 *fkattnum,
    8276             :                         Oid *pfeqoperators, Oid *ppeqoperators, Oid *ffeqoperators,
    8277             :                         bool old_check_ok, LOCKMODE lockmode)
    8278             : {
    8279         428 :     AssertArg(OidIsValid(parentConstr));
    8280             : 
    8281         428 :     if (rel->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_FOREIGN_TABLE)
    8282           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
    8283             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),
    8284             :                  errmsg("foreign key constraints are not supported on foreign tables")));
    8285             : 
    8286             :     /*
    8287             :      * If the referencing relation is a plain table, add the check triggers to
    8288             :      * it and, if necessary, schedule it to be checked in Phase 3.
    8289             :      *
    8290             :      * If the relation is partitioned, drill down to do it to its partitions.
    8291             :      */
    8292         428 :     if (rel->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_RELATION)
    8293             :     {
    8294         348 :         createForeignKeyCheckTriggers(RelationGetRelid(rel),
    8295             :                                       RelationGetRelid(pkrel),
    8296             :                                       fkconstraint,
    8297             :                                       parentConstr,
    8298             :                                       indexOid);
    8299             : 
    8300             :         /*
    8301             :          * Tell Phase 3 to check that the constraint is satisfied by existing
    8302             :          * rows. We can skip this during table creation, when requested
    8303             :          * explicitly by specifying NOT VALID in an ADD FOREIGN KEY command,
    8304             :          * and when we're recreating a constraint following a SET DATA TYPE
    8305             :          * operation that did not impugn its validity.
    8306             :          */
    8307         348 :         if (wqueue && !old_check_ok && !fkconstraint->skip_validation)
    8308             :         {
    8309             :             NewConstraint *newcon;
    8310             :             AlteredTableInfo *tab;

    8312         126 :             tab = ATGetQueueEntry(wqueue, rel);
    8313             : 
    8314         126 :             newcon = (NewConstraint *) palloc0(sizeof(NewConstraint));
    8315         126 :             newcon->name = get_constraint_name(parentConstr);
    8316         126 :             newcon->contype = CONSTR_FOREIGN;
    8317         126 :             newcon->refrelid = RelationGetRelid(pkrel);
    8318         126 :             newcon->refindid = indexOid;

    8320         126 :             newcon->qual = (Node *) fkconstraint;
    8321             : 
    8322         126 :             tab->constraints = lappend(tab->constraints, newcon);
    8323             :         }
    8324             :     }
    8325          80 :     else if (rel->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_PARTITIONED_TABLE)
    8326             :     {
    8327          80 :         PartitionDesc pd = RelationGetPartitionDesc(rel);
    8328             : 
    8329             :         /*
    8330             :          * Recurse to take appropriate action on each partition; either we
    8331             :          * find an existing constraint to reparent to ours, or we create a new
    8332             :          * one.
    8333             :          */
    8334         156 :         for (int i = 0; i < pd->nparts; i++)
    8335             :         {
    8336          76 :             Oid         partitionId = pd->oids[i];

    8351             :                                                 RelationGetDescr(rel));
    8352         188 :             for (int j = 0; j < numfks; j++)
    8353         112 :                 mapped_fkattnum[j] = attmap[fkattnum[j] - 1];
    8354             : 
    8355             :             /* Check whether an existing constraint can be repurposed */
    8356          76 :             partFKs = copyObject(RelationGetFKeyList(partition));
    8357          76 :             attached = false;
    8358          76 :             foreach(cell, partFKs)
    8359             :             {

    8361             :

    8363           4 :                 if (tryAttachPartitionForeignKey(fk,

    8366             :                                                  numfks,

    8368             :                                                  pkattnum,
    8369             :                                                  pfeqoperators))
    8370             :                 {
    8371           4 :                     attached = true;
    8372           4 :                     break;
    8373             :                 }
    8374             :             }
    8375          76 :             if (attached)
    8376             :             {
    8377           4 :                 table_close(partition, NoLock);
    8378           4 :                 continue;
    8379             :             }
    8380             : 
    8381             :             /*
    8382             :              * No luck finding a good constraint to reuse; create our own.
    8383             :              */
    8384          72 :             if (ConstraintNameIsUsed(CONSTRAINT_RELATION,
    8385             :                                      RelationGetRelid(partition),
    8386          72 :                                      fkconstraint->conname))
    8387           0 :                 conname = ChooseConstraintName(RelationGetRelationName(partition),
    8388           0 :                                                ChooseForeignKeyConstraintNameAddition(fkconstraint->fk_attrs),
    8389             :                                                "fkey",
    8390           0 :                                                RelationGetNamespace(partition), NIL);

    8454             : 
    8455             : /*
    8456             :  * CloneForeignKeyConstraints
    8457             :  *      Clone foreign keys from a partitioned table to a newly acquired
    8458             :  *      partition.
    8459             :  *
    8460             :  * partitionRel is a partition of parentRel, so we can be certain that it has
    8461             :  * the same columns with the same datatypes.  The columns may be in different
    8462             :  * order, though.
    8463             :  *
    8464             :  * wqueue must be passed to set up phase 3 constraint checking, unless the
    8465             :  * referencing-side partition is known to be empty (such as in CREATE TABLE /
    8466             :  * PARTITION OF).
    8467             :  */
    8468             : static void
    8469        1598 : CloneForeignKeyConstraints(List **wqueue, Relation parentRel,
    8470             :                            Relation partitionRel)
    8471             : {
    8472             :     /* This only works for declarative partitioning */
    8473        1598 :     Assert(parentRel->rd_rel->relkind == RELKIND_PARTITIONED_TABLE);
    8474             : 
    8475             :     /*
    8476             :      * Clone constraints for which the parent is on the referenced side.
    8477             :      */
    8478        1598 :     CloneFkReferenced(parentRel, partitionRel);
    8479             : 
    8480             :     /*
    8481             :      * Now clone constraints where the parent is on the referencing side.
    8482             :      */
    8483        1598 :     CloneFkReferencing(wqueue, parentRel, partitionRel);
    8484        1598 : }
    8485             : 
    8486             : /*
    8487             :  * CloneFkReferenced
    8488             :  *      Subroutine for CloneForeignKeyConstraints
    8489             :  *
    8490             :  * Find all the FKs that have the parent relation on the referenced side;
    8491             :  * clone those constraints to the given partition.  This is to be called
    8492             :  * when the partition is being created or attached.
    8493             :  *
    8494             :  * This recurses to partitions, if the relation being attached is partitioned.
    8495             :  * Recursion is done by calling addFkRecurseReferenced.
    8496             :  */
    8497             : static void
    8498        1598 : CloneFkReferenced(Relation parentRel, Relation partitionRel)
    8499             : {
    8500             :     Relation    pg_constraint;
    8501             :     AttrNumber *attmap;
    8502             :     ListCell   *cell;
    8503             :     SysScanDesc scan;
    8504             :     ScanKeyData key[2];
    8505             :     HeapTuple   tuple;
    8506        1598 :     List       *clone = NIL;
    8507             : 
    8508             :     /*
    8509             :      * Search for any constraints where this partition is in the referenced
    8510             :      * side.  However, we must ignore any constraint whose parent constraint
    8511             :      * is also going to be cloned, to avoid duplicates.  So do it in two
    8512             :      * steps: first construct the list of constraints to clone, then go over
    8513             :      * that list cloning those whose parents are not in the list.  (We must
    8514             :      * not rely on the parent being seen first, since the catalog scan could
    8515             :      * return children first.)
    8516             :      */
    8517        1598 :     pg_constraint = table_open(ConstraintRelationId, RowShareLock);
    8518        1598 :     ScanKeyInit(&key[0],
    8519             :                 Anum_pg_constraint_confrelid, BTEqualStrategyNumber,
    8520        1598 :                 F_OIDEQ, ObjectIdGetDatum(RelationGetRelid(parentRel)));
    8521        1598 :     ScanKeyInit(&key[1],
    8522             :                 Anum_pg_constraint_contype, BTEqualStrategyNumber,
    8523             :                 F_CHAREQ, CharGetDatum(CONSTRAINT_FOREIGN));
    8524             :     /* This is a seqscan, as we don't have a usable index ... */
    8525        1598 :     scan = systable_beginscan(pg_constraint, InvalidOid, true,
    8526             :                               NULL, 2, key);
    8527        3226 :     while ((tuple = systable_getnext(scan)) != NULL)
    8528             :     {
    8529          30 :         Form_pg_constraint constrForm = (Form_pg_constraint) GETSTRUCT(tuple);
    8530             : 
    8531             :         /* Only try to clone the top-level constraint; skip child ones. */
    8532          30 :         if (constrForm->conparentid != InvalidOid)
    8533          20 :             continue;
    8534             : 
    8535          10 :         clone = lappend_oid(clone, constrForm->oid);
    8536             :     }
    8537        1598 :     systable_endscan(scan);
    8538        1598 :     table_close(pg_constraint, RowShareLock);

    8540        1598 :     attmap = convert_tuples_by_name_map(RelationGetDescr(partitionRel),

    8542        1608 :     foreach(cell, clone)
    8543             :     {
    8544          10 :         Oid         constrOid = lfirst_oid(cell);

    8630             : 
    8631             : /*
    8632             :  * CloneFkReferencing
    8633             :  *      Subroutine for CloneForeignKeyConstraints
    8634             :  *
    8635             :  * For each FK constraint of the parent relation in the given list, find an
    8636             :  * equivalent constraint in its partition relation that can be reparented;
    8637             :  * if one cannot be found, create a new constraint in the partition as its
    8638             :  * child.
    8639             :  *
    8640             :  * If wqueue is given, it is used to set up phase-3 verification for each
    8641             :  * cloned constraint; if omitted, we assume that such verification is not
    8642             :  * needed (example: the partition is being created anew).
    8643             :  */
    8644             : static void
    8645        1598 : CloneFkReferencing(List **wqueue, Relation parentRel, Relation partRel)
    8646             : {
    8647             :     AttrNumber *attmap;
    8648             :     List       *partFKs;
    8649        1598 :     List       *clone = NIL;
    8650             :     ListCell   *cell;
    8651             : 
    8652             :     /* obtain a list of constraints that we need to clone */
    8653        1768 :     foreach(cell, RelationGetFKeyList(parentRel))
    8654             :     {
    8655         170 :         ForeignKeyCacheInfo *fk = lfirst(cell);
    8656             : 
    8657         170 :         clone = lappend_oid(clone, fk->conoid);
    8658             :     }
    8659             : 
    8660             :     /*
    8661             :      * Silently do nothing if there's nothing to do.  In particular, this
    8662             :      * avoids throwing a spurious error for foreign tables.
    8663             :      */

    8849             : }
    8850             : 
    8851             : /*
    8852             :  * When the parent of a partition receives [the referencing side of] a foreign
    8853             :  * key, we must propagate that foreign key to the partition.  However, the
    8854             :  * partition might already have an equivalent foreign key; this routine
    8855             :  * compares the given ForeignKeyCacheInfo (in the partition) to the FK defined
    8856             :  * by the other parameters.  If they are equivalent, create the link between
    8857             :  * the two constraints and return true.
    8858             :  *
    8859             :  * If the given FK does not match the one defined by rest of the params,
    8860             :  * return false.
    8861             :  */
    8862             : static bool
    8863          50 : tryAttachPartitionForeignKey(ForeignKeyCacheInfo *fk,
    8864             :                              Oid partRelid,
    8865             :                              Oid parentConstrOid,
    8866             :                              int numfks,
    8867             :                              AttrNumber *mapped_conkey,
    8868             :                              AttrNumber *confkey,
    8869             :                              Oid *conpfeqop)
    8870             : {
    8871             :     HeapTuple   parentConstrTup;
    8872             :     Form_pg_constraint parentConstr;
    8873             :     HeapTuple   partcontup;
    8874             :     Form_pg_constraint partConstr;
    8875             :     Relation    trigrel;
    8876             :     ScanKeyData key;
    8877             :     SysScanDesc scan;
    8878             :     HeapTuple   trigtup;
    8879             : 
    8880          50 :     parentConstrTup = SearchSysCache1(CONSTROID,
    8881             :                                       ObjectIdGetDatum(parentConstrOid));

    8932             :     /*
    8933             :      * Looks good!  Attach this constraint.  The action triggers in the new
    8934             :      * partition become redundant -- the parent table already has equivalent
    8935             :      * ones, and those will be able to reach the partition.  Remove the ones

    8960             :          * the two; however, since the trigger is no longer needed, we remove

    8984             : 
    8985             : /*
    8986             :  * ALTER TABLE ALTER CONSTRAINT
    8987             :  *
    8988             :  * Update the attributes of a constraint.
    8989             :  *
    8990             :  * Currently only works for Foreign Key constraints.
    8991             :  * Foreign keys do not inherit, so we purposely ignore the
    8992             :  * recursion bit here, but we keep the API the same for when
    8993             :  * other constraint types are supported.
    8994             :  *
    8995             :  * If the constraint is modified, returns its address; otherwise, return
    8996             :  * InvalidObjectAddress.
    8997             :  */

    9153             : /*
    9154             :  * ALTER TABLE VALIDATE CONSTRAINT
    9155             :  *
    9156             :  * XXX The reason we handle recursion here rather than at Phase 1 is because
    9157             :  * there's no good way to skip recursing when handling foreign keys: there is
    9158             :  * no need to lock children in that case, yet we wouldn't be able to avoid
    9159             :  * doing so at that level.
    9160             :  *
    9161             :  * Return value is the address of the validated constraint.  If the constraint
    9162             :  * was already validated, InvalidObjectAddress is returned.
    9163             :  */

    9165          46 : ATExecValidateConstraint(Relation rel, char *constrName, bool recurse,
    9166             :                          bool recursing, LOCKMODE lockmode)
    9167             : {
    9168             :     Relation    conrel;
    9169             :     SysScanDesc scan;
    9170             :     ScanKeyData skey[3];

    9172             :     Form_pg_constraint con;
    9173             :     ObjectAddress address;
    9174             : 
    9175          46 :     conrel = table_open(ConstraintRelationId, RowExclusiveLock);
    9176             : 
    9177             :     /*
    9178             :      * Find and check the target constraint
    9179             :      */
    9180          46 :     ScanKeyInit(&skey[0],
    9181             :                 Anum_pg_constraint_conrelid,
    9182             :                 BTEqualStrategyNumber, F_OIDEQ,

    9238             :         }
    9239          34 :         else if (con->contype == CONSTRAINT_CHECK)

    9321             : /*
    9322             :  * transformColumnNameList - transform list of column names

    9358             : 
    9359             : /*
    9360             :  * transformFkeyGetPrimaryKey -
    9361             :  *
    9362             :  *  Look up the names, attnums, and types of the primary key attributes
    9363             :  *  for the pkrel.  Also return the index OID and index opclasses of the
    9364             :  *  index supporting the primary key.
    9365             :  *
    9366             :  *  All parameters except pkrel are output parameters.  Also, the function
    9367             :  *  return value is the number of attributes in the primary key.
    9368             :  *
    9369             :  *  Used when the column list in the REFERENCES specification is omitted.
    9370             :  */
    9371             : static int
    9372         214 : transformFkeyGetPrimaryKey(Relation pkrel, Oid *indexOid,
    9373             :                            List **attnamelist,
    9374             :                            int16 *attnums, Oid *atttypids,
    9375             :                            Oid *opclasses)
    9376             : {
    9377             :     List       *indexoidlist;
    9378             :     ListCell   *indexoidscan;
    9379         214 :     HeapTuple   indexTuple = NULL;
    9380         214 :     Form_pg_index indexStruct = NULL;

    9382             :     bool        isnull;
    9383             :     oidvector  *indclass;
    9384             :     int         i;
    9385             : 
    9386             :     /*

    9388             :      * each one in the pg_index syscache until we find one marked primary key

    9459             : 
    9460             : /*
    9461             :  * transformFkeyCheckAttrs -
    9462             :  *
    9463             :  *  Make sure that the attributes of a referenced table belong to a unique
    9464             :  *  (or primary key) constraint.  Return the OID of the index supporting
    9465             :  *  the constraint, as well as the opclasses associated with the index
    9466             :  *  columns.
    9467             :  */
    9468             : static Oid
    9469         146 : transformFkeyCheckAttrs(Relation pkrel,
    9470             :                         int numattrs, int16 *attnums,
    9471             :                         Oid *opclasses) /* output parameter */
    9472             : {
    9473         146 :     Oid         indexoid = InvalidOid;
    9474         146 :     bool        found = false;
    9475         146 :     bool        found_deferrable = false;
    9476             :     List       *indexoidlist;
    9477             :     ListCell   *indexoidscan;
    9478             :     int         i,
    9479             :                 j;
    9480             : 
    9481             :     /*
    9482             :      * Reject duplicate appearances of columns in the referenced-columns list.
    9483             :      * Such a case is forbidden by the SQL standard, and even if we thought it
    9484             :      * useful to allow it, there would be ambiguity about how to match the
    9485             :      * list to unique indexes (in particular, it'd be unclear which index
    9486             :      * opclass goes with which FK column).
    9487             :      */
    9488         378 :     for (i = 0; i < numattrs; i++)
    9489             :     {
    9490         330 :         for (j = i + 1; j < numattrs; j++)
    9491             :         {
    9492          98 :             if (attnums[i] == attnums[j])
    9493           0 :                 ereport(ERROR,
    9494             :                         (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_FOREIGN_KEY),
    9495             :                          errmsg("foreign key referenced-columns list must not contain duplicates")));
    9496             :         }
    9497             :     }
    9498             : 
    9499             :     /*
    9500             :      * Get the list of index OIDs for the table from the relcache, and look up
    9501             :      * each one in the pg_index syscache, and match unique indexes to the list
    9502             :      * of attnums we are given.
    9503             :      */
    9504         146 :     indexoidlist = RelationGetIndexList(pkrel);
    9505             : 
    9506         204 :     foreach(indexoidscan, indexoidlist)
    9507             :     {
    9508             :         HeapTuple   indexTuple;

    9510             :

    9513         200 :         if (!HeapTupleIsValid(indexTuple))
    9514           0 :             elog(ERROR, "cache lookup failed for index %u", indexoid);
    9515         200 :         indexStruct = (Form_pg_index) GETSTRUCT(indexTuple);
    9516             : 
    9517             :         /*

    9520             :          * indexes are out as well.
    9521             :          */

    9534             :                                             Anum_pg_index_indclass, &isnull);

    9536         160 :             indclass = (oidvector *) DatumGetPointer(indclassDatum);
    9537             : 
    9538             :             /*
    9539             :              * The given attnum list may match the index columns in any order.
    9540             :              * Check for a match, and extract the appropriate opclasses while
    9541             :              * we're at it.
    9542             :              *
    9543             :              * We know that attnums[] is duplicate-free per the test at the
    9544             :              * start of this function, and we checked above that the number of
    9545             :              * index columns agrees, so if we find a match for each attnums[]

    9557         228 :                         break;
    9558             :                     }
    9559             :                 }
    9560         246 :                 if (!found)
    9561          18 :                     break;
    9562             :             }
    9563             : 
    9564             :             /*

    9603             : /*

    9632             : /*

    9661             : /*

    9748         130 : validateForeignKeyConstraint(char *conname,
    9749             :                              Relation rel,

    9839             : 
    9840             : static void
    9841         696 : CreateFKCheckTrigger(Oid myRelOid, Oid refRelOid, Constraint *fkconstraint,
    9842             :                      Oid constraintOid, Oid indexOid, bool on_insert)
    9843             : {
    9844             :     CreateTrigStmt *fk_trigger;
    9845             : 
    9846             :     /*
    9847             :      * Note: for a self-referential FK (referencing and referenced tables are
    9848             :      * the same), it is important that the ON UPDATE action fires before the
    9849             :      * CHECK action, since both triggers will fire on the same row during an
    9850             :      * UPDATE event; otherwise the CHECK trigger will be checking a non-final
    9851             :      * state of the row.  Triggers fire in name order, so we ensure this by
    9852             :      * using names like "RI_ConstraintTrigger_a_NNNN" for the action triggers
    9853             :      * and "RI_ConstraintTrigger_c_NNNN" for the check triggers.
    9854             :      */
    9855         696 :     fk_trigger = makeNode(CreateTrigStmt);
    9856         696 :     fk_trigger->trigname = "RI_ConstraintTrigger_c";
    9857         696 :     fk_trigger->relation = NULL;
    9858         696 :     fk_trigger->row = true;
    9859         696 :     fk_trigger->timing = TRIGGER_TYPE_AFTER;
    9860             : 
    9861             :     /* Either ON INSERT or ON UPDATE */
    9862         696 :     if (on_insert)
    9863             :     {
    9864         348 :         fk_trigger->funcname = SystemFuncName("RI_FKey_check_ins");
    9865         348 :         fk_trigger->events = TRIGGER_TYPE_INSERT;
    9866             :     }
    9867             :     else
    9868             :     {
    9869         348 :         fk_trigger->funcname = SystemFuncName("RI_FKey_check_upd");
    9870         348 :         fk_trigger->events = TRIGGER_TYPE_UPDATE;
    9871             :     }
    9872             : 
    9873         696 :     fk_trigger->columns = NIL;
    9874         696 :     fk_trigger->transitionRels = NIL;
    9875         696 :     fk_trigger->whenClause = NULL;
    9876         696 :     fk_trigger->isconstraint = true;
    9877         696 :     fk_trigger->deferrable = fkconstraint->deferrable;
    9878         696 :     fk_trigger->initdeferred = fkconstraint->initdeferred;
    9879         696 :     fk_trigger->constrrel = NULL;
    9880         696 :     fk_trigger->args = NIL;
    9881             : 
    9882         696 :     (void) CreateTrigger(fk_trigger, NULL, myRelOid, refRelOid, constraintOid,

   10027             :  * ALTER TABLE DROP CONSTRAINT
   10028             :  *
   10029             :  * Like DROP COLUMN, we can't use the normal ALTER TABLE recursion mechanism.
   10030             :  */

   10267             : /*
   10268             :  * ALTER COLUMN TYPE
   10269             :  */
   10270             : static void
   10271         274 : ATPrepAlterColumnType(List **wqueue,
   10272             :                       AlteredTableInfo *tab, Relation rel,
   10273             :                       bool recurse, bool recursing,
   10274             :                       AlterTableCmd *cmd, LOCKMODE lockmode)
   10275             : {
   10276         274 :     char       *colName = cmd->name;
   10277         274 :     ColumnDef  *def = (ColumnDef *) cmd->def;

   10279         274 :     Node       *transform = def->cooked_default;

   10290             :

   10292           2 :         ereport(ERROR,
   10293             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),
   10294             :                  errmsg("cannot alter column type of typed table")));

   10299           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
   10300             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_UNDEFINED_COLUMN),

   10302             :                         colName, RelationGetRelationName(rel))));

   10304         272 :     attnum = attTup->attnum;

   10306             :     /* Can't alter a system attribute */

   10308           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
   10309             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_FEATURE_NOT_SUPPORTED),
   10310             :                  errmsg("cannot alter system column \"%s\"",
   10311             :                         colName)));

   10313             :     /*
   10314             :      * Don't alter inherited columns.  At outer level, there had better not be

   10316             :      * the parent level (see below).

   10318         272 :     if (attTup->attinhcount > 0 && !recursing)
   10319           2 :         ereport(ERROR,

   10321             :                  errmsg("cannot alter inherited column \"%s\"",
   10322             :                         colName)));
   10323             : 
   10324             :     /* Don't alter columns used in the partition key */

   10328           6 :         ereport(ERROR,

   10332             : 
   10333             :     /* Look up the target type */

   10335             :

   10339             : 
   10340             :     /* And the collation */
   10341         260 :     targetcollid = GetColumnDefCollation(NULL, def, targettype);
   10342             : 
   10343             :     /* make sure datatype is legal for a column */
   10344         260 :     CheckAttributeType(colName, targettype, targetcollid,
   10345         260 :                        list_make1_oid(rel->rd_rel->reltype),
   10346             :                        0);
   10347             : 
   10348         312 :     if (tab->relkind == RELKIND_RELATION ||
   10349          54 :         tab->relkind == RELKIND_PARTITIONED_TABLE)
   10350             :     {
   10351             :         /*
   10352             :          * Set up an expression to transform the old data value to the new
   10353             :          * type. If a USING option was given, use the expression as
   10354             :          * transformed by transformAlterTableStmt, else just take the old
   10355             :          * value and try to coerce it.  We do this first so that type
   10356             :          * incompatibility can be detected before we waste effort, and because
   10357             :          * we need the expression to be parsed against the original table row
   10358             :          * type.
   10359             :          */
   10360         220 :         if (!transform)

   10363             :                                          attTup->atttypid, attTup->atttypmod,
   10364             :                                          attTup->attcollation,
   10365             :                                          0);
   10366             :         }
   10367             : 
   10368         220 :         transform = coerce_to_target_type(pstate,
   10369             :                                           transform, exprType(transform),
   10370             :                                           targettype, targettypmod,
   10371             :                                           COERCION_ASSIGNMENT,
   10372             :                                           COERCE_IMPLICIT_CAST,
   10373             :                                           -1);
   10374         220 :         if (transform == NULL)
   10375             :         {
   10376             :             /* error text depends on whether USING was specified or not */
   10377           6 :             if (def->cooked_default != NULL)
   10378           2 :                 ereport(ERROR,
   10379             :                         (errcode(ERRCODE_DATATYPE_MISMATCH),
   10380             :                          errmsg("result of USING clause for column \"%s\""
   10381             :                                 " cannot be cast automatically to type %s",
   10382             :                                 colName, format_type_be(targettype)),
   10383             :                          errhint("You might need to add an explicit cast.")));
   10384             :             else
   10385           4 :                 ereport(ERROR,
   10386             :                         (errcode(ERRCODE_DATATYPE_MISMATCH),
   10387             :                          errmsg("column \"%s\" cannot be cast automatically to type %s",

   10400         214 :         transform = (Node *) expression_planner((Expr *) transform);

   10413             :     }
   10414          38 :     else if (transform)
   10415           4 :         ereport(ERROR,
   10416             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_WRONG_OBJECT_TYPE),
   10417             :                  errmsg("\"%s\" is not a table",
   10418             :                         RelationGetRelationName(rel))));
   10419             : 
   10420         476 :     if (tab->relkind == RELKIND_COMPOSITE_TYPE ||
   10421         228 :         tab->relkind == RELKIND_FOREIGN_TABLE)
   10422             :     {
   10423             :         /*

   10425             :          * when the table is being rewritten.
   10426             :          */
   10427          34 :         find_composite_type_dependencies(rel->rd_rel->reltype, rel, NULL);
   10428             :     }
   10429             : 
   10430         242 :     ReleaseSysCache(tuple);
   10431             : 
   10432             :     /*
   10433             :      * Recurse manually by queueing a new command for each child, if
   10434             :      * necessary. We cannot apply ATSimpleRecursion here because we need to
   10435             :      * remap attribute numbers in the USING expression, if any.
   10436             :      *
   10437             :      * If we are told not to recurse, there had better not be any child
   10438             :      * tables; else the alter would put them out of step.
   10439             :      */
   10440         242 :     if (recurse)
   10441             :     {
   10442         164 :         Oid         relid = RelationGetRelid(rel);
   10443             :         List       *child_oids,
   10444             :                    *child_numparents;

   10451             :         /*
   10452             :          * find_all_inheritors does the recursive search of the inheritance
   10453             :          * hierarchy, so all we have to do is process all of the relids in the
   10454             :          * list that it returns.
   10455             :          */
   10456         390 :         forboth(lo, child_oids, li, child_numparents)
   10457             :         {
   10458         234 :             Oid         childrelid = lfirst_oid(lo);

   10465         164 :                 continue;

   10467             :             /* find_all_inheritors already got lock */
   10468          70 :             childrel = relation_open(childrelid, NoLock);
   10469          70 :             CheckTableNotInUse(childrel, "ALTER TABLE");

   10475             :              * because of its different recursion mechanism.)

   10478             :                                                colName);

   10529             :                         colName)));

   10532          16 :         ATTypedTableRecursion(wqueue, rel, cmd, lockmode);
   10533         232 : }
   10534             : 
   10535             : /*
   10536             :  * When the data type of a column is changed, a rewrite might not be required
   10537             :  * if the new type is sufficiently identical to the old one, and the USING
   10538             :  * clause isn't trying to insert some other value.  It's safe to skip the
   10539             :  * rewrite in these cases:
   10540             :  *
   10541             :  * - the old type is binary coercible to the new type
   10542             :  * - the new type is an unconstrained domain over the old type
   10543             :  * - {NEW,OLD} or {OLD,NEW} is {timestamptz,timestamp} and the timezone is UTC
   10544             :  *
   10545             :  * In the case of a constrained domain, we could get by with scanning the
   10546             :  * table and checking the constraint rather than actually rewriting it, but we
   10547             :  * don't currently try to do that.
   10548             :  */
   10549             : static bool
   10550         214 : ATColumnChangeRequiresRewrite(Node *expr, AttrNumber varattno)
   10551             : {
   10552         214 :     Assert(expr != NULL);
   10553             : 
   10554             :     for (;;)
   10555             :     {
   10556             :         /* only one varno, so no need to check that */
   10557         236 :         if (IsA(expr, Var) &&((Var *) expr)->varattno == varattno)
   10558          42 :             return false;
   10559         194 :         else if (IsA(expr, RelabelType))
   10560          18 :             expr = (Node *) ((RelabelType *) expr)->arg;
   10561         176 :         else if (IsA(expr, CoerceToDomain))
   10562             :         {
   10563           0 :             CoerceToDomain *d = (CoerceToDomain *) expr;
   10564             : 
   10565           0 :             if (DomainHasConstraints(d->resulttype))
   10566           0 :                 return true;
   10567           0 :             expr = (Node *) d->arg;
   10568             :         }
   10569         176 :         else if (IsA(expr, FuncExpr))
   10570             :         {
   10571         126 :             FuncExpr   *f = (FuncExpr *) expr;
   10572             : 
   10573         126 :             switch (f->funcid)
   10574             :             {
   10575             :                 case F_TIMESTAMPTZ_TIMESTAMP:
   10576             :                 case F_TIMESTAMP_TIMESTAMPTZ:
   10577           6 :                     if (TimestampTimestampTzRequiresRewrite())
   10578           2 :                         return true;
   10579             :                     else
   10580           4 :                         expr = linitial(f->args);
   10581           4 :                     break;
   10582             :                 default:
   10583         120 :                     return true;
   10584             :             }
   10585             :         }
   10586             :         else
   10587          50 :             return true;
   10588          22 :     }
   10589             : }
   10590             : 
   10591             : /*
   10592             :  * ALTER COLUMN .. SET DATA TYPE
   10593             :  *
   10594             :  * Return the address of the modified column.
   10595             :  */
   10596             : static ObjectAddress
   10597         224 : ATExecAlterColumnType(AlteredTableInfo *tab, Relation rel,

   10619             : 
   10620             :     /*
   10621             :      * Clear all the missing values if we're rewriting the table, since this

   10625             :     {
   10626             :         Relation    newrel;

   10643             :                         colName, RelationGetRelationName(rel))));

   10662             : 
   10663             :     /*
   10664             :      * If there is a default expression for the column, get it and ensure we
   10665             :      * can coerce it to the new datatype.  (We must do this before changing
   10666             :      * the column type, because build_column_default itself will try to
   10667             :      * coerce, and will not issue the error message we want if it fails.)
   10668             :      *
   10669             :      * We remove any implicit coercion steps at the top level of the old
   10670             :      * default expression; this has been agreed to satisfy the principle of
   10671             :      * least surprise.  (The conversion to the new column type should act like
   10672             :      * it started from what the user sees as the stored expression, and the
   10673             :      * implicit coercions aren't going to be shown.)
   10674             :      */
   10675         224 :     if (attTup->atthasdef)
   10676             :     {

   10703             :     /*

   10802             :             case OCLASS_TRIGGER:

   10804             :                 /*
   10805             :                  * A trigger can depend on a column because the column is
   10806             :                  * specified as an update target, or because the column is
   10807             :                  * used in the trigger's WHEN condition.  The first case would
   10808             :                  * not require any extra work, but the second case would
   10809             :                  * require updating the WHEN expression, which will take a
   10810             :                  * significant amount of new code.  Since we can't easily tell
   10811             :                  * which case applies, we punt for both.  FIXME someday.
   10812             :                  */
   10813           0 :                 ereport(ERROR,

   10824             :                  * A policy can depend on a column because the column is
   10825             :                  * specified in the policy's USING or WITH CHECK qual

   10827             :                  * the policy expression, but punt for now.  It's certainly
   10828             :                  * easy enough to remove and recreate the policy; still, FIXME
   10829             :                  * someday.
   10830             :                  */
   10831           0 :                 ereport(ERROR,

   10834             :                          errdetail("%s depends on column \"%s\"",
   10835             :                                    getObjectDescription(&foundObject),
   10836             :                                    colName)));

   10838             : 
   10839             :             case OCLASS_DEFAULT:

   10842             :                  * Ignore the column's default expression, since we will fix
   10843             :                  * it below.

   10847             : 
   10848             :             case OCLASS_STATISTIC_EXT:

   10852             :                  * that this column type change would break.
   10853             :                  */
   10854           4 :                 UpdateStatisticsForTypeChange(foundObject.objectId,

   10858             : 
   10859             :             case OCLASS_PROC:

   10892             :                  * We don't expect any of these sorts of objects to depend on
   10893             :                  * a column.
   10894             :                  */

   10896             :                      getObjectDescription(&foundObject));

   10901             :                  * compiler to warn if a new OCLASS hasn't been handled above.

   10908             :     /*

   11088             : /*
   11089             :  * Subroutine for ATExecAlterColumnType: remember that a constraint needs
   11090             :  * to be rebuilt (which we might already know).

   11092             : static void
   11093         116 : RememberConstraintForRebuilding(Oid conoid, AlteredTableInfo *tab)
   11094             : {
   11095             :     /*
   11096             :      * This de-duplication check is critical for two independent reasons: we
   11097             :      * mustn't try to recreate the same constraint twice, and if a constraint
   11098             :      * depends on more than one column whose type is to be altered, we must
   11099             :      * capture its definition string before applying any of the column type
   11100             :      * changes.  ruleutils.c will get confused if we ask again later.
   11101             :      */
   11102         116 :     if (!list_member_oid(tab->changedConstraintOids, conoid))
   11103             :     {
   11104             :         /* OK, capture the constraint's existing definition string */

   11119          62 : RememberIndexForRebuilding(Oid indoid, AlteredTableInfo *tab)
   11120             : {

   11122             :      * This de-duplication check is critical for two independent reasons: we
   11123             :      * mustn't try to recreate the same index twice, and if an index depends
   11124             :      * on more than one column whose type is to be altered, we must capture
   11125             :      * its definition string before applying any of the column type changes.

   11129             :     {

   11131             :          * Before adding it as an index-to-rebuild, we'd better see if it
   11132             :          * belongs to a constraint, and if so rebuild the constraint instead.

   11134             :          * have only dependencies on their constraint.  But it's possible for

   11156             : 
   11157             : /*
   11158             :  * Cleanup after we've finished all the ALTER TYPE operations for a
   11159             :  * particular relation.  We have to drop and recreate all the indexes
   11160             :  * and constraints that depend on the altered columns.  We do the
   11161             :  * actual dropping here, but re-creation is managed by adding work
   11162             :  * queue entries to do those steps later.
   11163             :  */
   11164             : static void
   11165         210 : ATPostAlterTypeCleanup(List **wqueue, AlteredTableInfo *tab, LOCKMODE lockmode)
   11166             : {
   11167             :     ObjectAddress obj;
   11168             :     ObjectAddresses *objects;
   11169             :     ListCell   *def_item;
   11170             :     ListCell   *oid_item;
   11171             : 
   11172             :     /*
   11173             :      * Collect all the constraints and indexes to drop so we can process them
   11174             :      * in a single call.  That way we don't have to worry about dependencies
   11175             :      * among them.
   11176             :      */
   11177         210 :     objects = new_object_addresses();
   11178             : 
   11179             :     /*
   11180             :      * Re-parse the index and constraint definitions, and attach them to the
   11181             :      * appropriate work queue entries.  We do this before dropping because in
   11182             :      * the case of a FOREIGN KEY constraint, we might not yet have exclusive
   11183             :      * lock on the table the constraint is attached to, and we need to get
   11184             :      * that before reparsing/dropping.
   11185             :      *
   11186             :      * We can't rely on the output of deparsing to tell us which relation to
   11187             :      * operate on, because concurrent activity might have made the name
   11188             :      * resolve differently.  Instead, we've got to use the OID of the
   11189             :      * constraint or index we're processing to figure out which relation to
   11190             :      * operate on.
   11191             :      */
   11192         302 :     forboth(oid_item, tab->changedConstraintOids,
   11193             :             def_item, tab->changedConstraintDefs)
   11194             :     {
   11195          92 :         Oid         oldId = lfirst_oid(oid_item);
   11196             :         HeapTuple   tup;
   11197             :         Form_pg_constraint con;
   11198             :         Oid         relid;
   11199             :         Oid         confrelid;
   11200             :         char        contype;
   11201             :         bool        conislocal;
   11202             : 
   11203          92 :         tup = SearchSysCache1(CONSTROID, ObjectIdGetDatum(oldId));
   11204          92 :         if (!HeapTupleIsValid(tup)) /* should not happen */
   11205           0 :             elog(ERROR, "cache lookup failed for constraint %u", oldId);
   11206          92 :         con = (Form_pg_constraint) GETSTRUCT(tup);
   11207          92 :         if (OidIsValid(con->conrelid))
   11208          88 :             relid = con->conrelid;
   11209             :         else
   11210             :         {
   11211             :             /* must be a domain constraint */
   11212           4 :             relid = get_typ_typrelid(getBaseType(con->contypid));
   11213           4 :             if (!OidIsValid(relid))
   11214           0 :                 elog(ERROR, "could not identify relation associated with constraint %u", oldId);
   11215             :         }
   11216          92 :         confrelid = con->confrelid;
   11217          92 :         contype = con->contype;
   11218          92 :         conislocal = con->conislocal;
   11219          92 :         ReleaseSysCache(tup);
   11220             : 
   11221          92 :         ObjectAddressSet(obj, ConstraintRelationId, oldId);
   11222          92 :         add_exact_object_address(&obj, objects);
   11223             : 
   11224             :         /*
   11225             :          * If the constraint is inherited (only), we don't want to inject a
   11226             :          * new definition here; it'll get recreated when ATAddCheckConstraint
   11227             :          * recurses from adding the parent table's constraint.  But we had to
   11228             :          * carry the info this far so that we can drop the constraint below.
   11229             :          */
   11230          92 :         if (!conislocal)
   11231           4 :             continue;
   11232             :

   11234             :          * When rebuilding an FK constraint that references the table we're
   11235             :          * modifying, we might not yet have any lock on the FK's table, so get

   11241             :

   11243          88 :                              (char *) lfirst(def_item),

   11245             :     }
   11246         266 :     forboth(oid_item, tab->changedIndexOids,
   11247             :             def_item, tab->changedIndexDefs)
